div.p: THE Bragadocio; OR, THE Bawd turn'd Puritan: A NEW COMEDY.
By a Perſon of Quality.
Licenſed,
LONDON, Printed for Richard Baldwin, near the Oxford-Arms in Warwick-Lane, 1691.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae:

list.label: Bragadocio, or Bravado
list.item: A Triumphing Coward, but a great Pretender to Courage, and proud to be thought a Debauchee.
list.label: Sir Popular Jealous—
list.item: A Seditious Magiſtrate, that Patroniſes the People only to ſerve his own ends oſ 'em.
list.label: Shuffle—
list.item: Naturally of good Principles, but forc't to Countenance the Faction through Neceſſity.
list.label: Roman—
list.item: A Gentleman of a low Fortune, but very Honourable.
list.label: Sir Credulous Trinket—
list.item: One that knows nothing of the World; inclin'd to Melancholy, and always Freikiſh, and Superſtitious.
list.label: Fluſh—
list.item: Of good Parts, but a rambling, hot-headed Blade; and rails againſt his Univerſity through Diſcontent.
list.label: Toper—
list.item: Fluſh's Companion, but a meer Sot.
list.label: Jeffry—
Gullman—
list.item: An old Bawd that deſerts her Vocation, and ſets up for a Fortune; Marry'd to Sir Popular.
list.label: Juliana— Carolietta—
Amazonia—
list.item: Toper's Wife, a Virago that Tyranniſes over her Husband, only to ſerve her ſelf of Opportunities to Cuckold him.
list.label: Faith—

div.p: A Jeweller, a Quack, a Milliner, a Sollicitor, a Pimp, a Carrier, a Coffee-Man, Bullies, Serjeants, Tradeſmen, and Attendants.
SCENE, London.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
Books lately Printed, and Sold by Tho. Salusbury, at the Sign of the Temple, near Temple-Barr in Fleet-ſtreet.
div.p: THe Hiſtory of the Late Great Revolution in England and Scotland, with the Cauſes and Means by which it was Accompliſhed. Together with a Particular Account of the Extraordinary Occurrences which happened thereupon. As likewiſe the Settlement of both the Kingdoms under their Moſt Serene Majeſties King William and Queen Mary. Price 5 s.

The Safety of France to Monſieur the Dauphin: Or, the Secret Hiſtory of the French King. Proving to his Son that there is no other way to ſecure France from approaching Ruine, but by Depoſing his Father for a Tyrant and Deſtroyer of his People.

The Art of Brewing Beer, Ale, and other ſorts of Liquors, ſo as to render them more healthful to the Body, and agreeable to Nature, and to keep them longer from ſouring, with leſs Trouble and Charge than generally practiſed, which will be a means to prevent thoſe torturing Diſtempers of the Stone, Gravel, Gout, and Dropſie.

A Collection of many Wonderful Propheſies, relating to the Engliſh Nation; Plainly Foretelling the late Great Revolution, and Happy Settlement of this Kingdom; his preſent Majeſties Succeſſes in Ireland, and particularly his Victory at the Boyne, and the Action at Sea betwixt both Fleets; with other very Remarkable Things not yet come to paſs.

Miſcellany Poems, viz. 1. Remarks on the Death of King Charles the II. 2. On the Succeſſion of King James the II. 3. Upon Faith. 4. Upon Patience. V. Upon Ambition. VI. To the Univerſity of Oxford. VII. The Soul to a Good Conſcience. VIII. The Soul to a Bad Conſcience.

The Declaration and Manifeſto of the Proteſtants of the Vallies of Piedmont, called the Vaudois, to all Chriſtian Princes and States, of the Reaſons of their taking up Arms juſt now againſt the Duke of Savoy. And why they have put themſelves under the Protection of William, King of Great Britain, and of the Evangelick Cantons of Switzerland.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: BUT do'e reſolve, ſay you, never to viſit the Univerſity again?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Not till Idleneſs and Hypocriſie be as much out o' faſhion as Learning;—I'll ſooner herd with Savages in a Deſart, where hungry Nature's the ſole Tutoreſs.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —This is juſt ſuch a quarrel, as a Presbyter has againſt Epiſcopacy;—I am confident ſome Preferment there, wou'd reconcile you,

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Prythee don't miſtake me;—I never had the vanity to think I deſerv'd it; but tho' I had engroſſed all the Morals, that ever the learned Antients taught, they wou'd not ha'been proof againſt Exceptions.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —No!—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —No o' my Conſcience,—I have known a worthy Fellow that has been learned as the Sybils, but modeſt religiouſly obſervant as the Veſtals;—Still and reſerved as the Night, yet cheerful as the Morning;—temperate and ſtrict as an Anchorite, and complying as unpractis'd Youth.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Sure none cou'd object againſt ſo fair a Character.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p:
—Yes,—a tedious Blockhead, ſcare capable of an Ordinary's Office at the Reading of a Neck-Verſe, ſhall cavil againſt his Schollarſhip;—then comes a ſecond ſpitting pimpl'd Sot, and ſhall firſt hyccup in his Face, then tell him, he's a Company-keeper,
when at the ſame time the dizzie Ape can ſcarce faulter out his unjuſt Exception;—thus all of 'em after a ſucceſſive diſcovery of Ignorance, and ill Principles, ſhall prefer a deſertleſs Dunce to an accompliſh't Candidate.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Prithee what kind of Complexion'd People do your Sages approve on, as beſt qualifi'd for their preferment?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Such eaſie ſuff'ring Sots as have liv'd in due obſervance of their Inſolent Grandure, and Ridiculous Statelineſs, that have no ſenſe to diſcover the want on't in them, and will ſuffer themſelves to be ſolemnly cheated, and never take notice on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Noble Gentlemen, I am your Creature.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —It muſt be an affair of grand concern that brings you hither, Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Without Ceremony Gentlemen, I have no other buſineſs at preſent, than to invite you to the chaſe of a crippl'd Worm hunted by a couple of lame Snails.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Wee'll attend your noble diverſion.—

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Well, but don't let his impertinence divert your diſcourſe; pray continue it, and acquaint me with the order of their Diſcipline.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Order! ha, ha—you'll find no more there, than in Darius's Army againſt Alexander;—Arts and Sciences are promiſcuous with Tricks and Debaucheries.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay!—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —'Tis an imperfect Emblem of the Chaos, where Bodies of ſtrange form and figure were hudl'd up together in a diſagreeing concord.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: An Univerſal Medly indeed!—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: You ſhall have a ſerious old Homiliſt making his unfaſhionable Chamber-love to a tractable Laundreſs,—a young breeding Heir penning Madrigals on his Bed-maker, or Philliſing the Skull's Daughter;—and a leading Tutor turning off an old Tradeſman, becauſe ſome Upſtart has got a handſom Wife.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —But as to the buſineſs of Learning;—is not that promoted now-a-days?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Yes, as thus—you ſhall hear a couple of old Caſuiſts, ſplutter their mouldy Notions, and intricate Terms in one another's Faces, The one labouring with remote Fetches, to ſalve the opinion of a contradicting Dogmatiſt, whilſt the other bladders him with broken Latine, tranſgreſſing form, and confounding Axioms; then like two batter'd Game-Cocks, the laſt word gets the Victory.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —They are very laborious upon't it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —No, no,—They are too great to take pains;—I have known a Reverend poring Doctor, that has ſwouned half an Age over a St. Auſtin; and if he chanc'd to mount the Pulpit but once in ſeven years, wou'd after a Praeludium of Hems, ſlyly draw his Memory out of his Pocket, and repeat the Opinions of the Voluminous Fathers, then conclude with an Harangue againſt Court Vanities, becauſe ſome promiſing Lord has fail'd to make him a Biſhop.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You are reſolv'd to ſpare none from the Scarlet Doctor to the draggl'd Soph.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Some few good well principl'd men there is in their Society, but like a Loyalliſt in a Faction, they muſt either comply or be abhorr'd. — But Pry—the let's goe, we ſhall be too late elſe in good ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You may if you pleaſe, but I muſt wait here for a Gentleman; if ſome thing ſhou'd detain me, do ſo much as excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Was this Fluſh I met upon the Stairs?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay; He has been Railing at his Univerſity like a ſuſpended Parſon.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: He's one o' thoſe lewd profligate Wretches that diſhonour all places of civil Education, becauſe their own looſe behaviour is diſcountenane'd and upbraided there.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He's above that vain thing call'd Learning, he may thank his Genisu.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Which way is he gone?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: To the Palsgrave's-Head; the truth on't is, I engag'd my Word to be there too, But now I think on't, I'll diſpoſe o' my ſelf otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: You have ſome rich beardleſs Foo! or other to manage;—hang't, 'tis time to give it over now.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Your Servant good generous Sir; ▪ I think 'tis more prudence to Thrive and Rook whilſt I'm Young, and ſo prevent it in my Old Age, then be forc'd to't in theſe Days, and ſo have reaſon to condemn the negligence of my Youth.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Truly, a Cheat at Threeſcore, is as Odious as a Uſurer at Twenty.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: And a Knave without neceſſity is as unpardonable as a Mercenary Matron that's Rich and Ugly.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I'll aſſure you Shuffle, I alwaies believ'd your Principle to be ſo far honourable, as that nothing but the ſevere impulſe of neceſſity cou'd ſhake 'em: I have obſerv'd with what an honeſt Calmneſs, and even tranquility of Mind, you have born diſappointments, and have pitty'd you ſeveral times when I cou'd not help you.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Certainly my needs are ſo violent they cannot continue long; however, whilſt I am concern'd with Sir Credulous Trinket, and Sir Populer, I muſt not think of a Reformation.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Sir Credulous Trincket, That's my Rival; Pry-thee what ſort of a Gentleman is he? I have not the honour of his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You are very unhappy in't, I'll promiſe you; He's a moſt facetious Perſon in his way; —firſt he read himſelf into Melancholly, then was advis'd to Travel as an expedient, which he undertook, and is now return'd Freakiſh and Superſtitious; he knows nothing o'the World, and is impos'd upon by every one.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I have had ſuch an account of him— Well but I have wonder'd oft how you contracted this intimacy with Sir Populer?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p:
Firſt I got repute amongſt his Creatures, and ſo had the
opportunity of hearing him, and being in his Company long I diſcover'd him; which he perceiv'd, and thereupon declar'd himſelf to me; ſince we have unanimouſly Whedl'd our Blewapron Men— the deſign on't you may Interpret eaſily.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ay, I can apprehend it;— It ſeems now you have taught your Spirit to Truckle to your Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I can out cant a Tubſter, out fawn a Rook, out promiſe a Courtier, and out ſwear an Evidence.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I know your Buſineſs, here's a Gentleman with me now, but I ſhall be glad to ſee you to Morrow Morning.
A Pox o'theſe Dunns, they are as conſtant in a Morning as the Milk-woman;—I have warn'd the Houſe I know not how oft to deny me to all Viſitants without Swords.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Poor Shuffle!—Faith I never reſented my own Condition more ſenſibly than now;—I am only ſorry my fortunes are ſo Scant, becauſe I cannot ſupply thee;—Come along with me, I'll try the extent of my Credit.

div.head: SCENE. II. Sir Credulous's Houſe, an Anti-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Your Approbation Captain, your Approbation; did you ever hear a Mag-pye diſcourſe more Ingeniouſly, or greater Reaſon ſince you were a Gentleman? Did ye?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs not uſually.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Uſually; did you ever? Speak.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: To be plain with you, Sir Cred. once I did, but it was at Paris;—I heard one there that had more French then ſeveral of your Gentry that had reſided there ſome Years; it got my Name and Quality preſently, I had a Familiar acquaintance with it.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: And learn'd all his French from it, I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Well, but conſider Captain, my Mag has not had the advantage of ſuch a Gentleman's Converſation as your ſelf; it was bred a plain Country Bird, and had no other Tutor till I came to Town, than the Curate.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: A very promiſing Mag!

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: There was an Illiterate Cox-comb, t'other day, told me he wou'd not give me 5 Guineas for't.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Some rude undervaluing Ruſtick that underſtood not its excellencies.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But was your ſhattering acquaintance ſo accompliſht in good earneſt?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: It deſerves a Panegyrick as well as ſome of our modern Heroes; It wou'd tell you i' the Night-time what a Clock, as exactly as the Bell-man; wou'd talk as quaintly upon occaſion as an affected Citizen; wou'd repartee as ſmartly as a Mask in the Gallery:—ſeveral of our travelling Fops deriv'd from it their ſcraps of Complaiſance, and little civil Impertinencies, they are daily troubleſom with in Park and Play-houſe.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: If it was not for theſe French Mag-pyes, I geſs we ſhou'd not have ſo many Engliſh Owles.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But Captain, I'll preſume to tell you, I can ſhow you as great Rarities as all your Travels cou'd entertain you with.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: My Curioſity will be oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Jeffry! Here, take the Key of my Cloſet, and bring me Liſp and Quaker.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: What are theſe Sir Cred?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Brace of Animals, which the Vulgar take for Dogs; ſeriouſly, they reſemble 'em ſo much, you'll ſcarce diſtinguiſh till you hear 'em diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Sir you had left your Cloſet door unlockt, and Liſp's got out; one o'the Grooms told me he's gone to wait upon Sir Populer's Bitch home.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Very probable, he was alwaies an obliging courteous Creature;—But where's Quaker?

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Sir, he preſents his ſervice to you, and deſires you to excuſe him, he's ingag'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ingag'd! Where, and upon what account?

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: With a Bone Sir, under the Dreſſer-board.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: No, no, his abſence cannot be diſpenc'd with;—go and conduct him in immediately;—be as quick as a Juggler's hand.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Piſh,—I have as many Fools Errands to run upon, as a well-meaning April-Bird.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Pray reſolve me, Sir Cred. what theſe two Prodigies are deſign'd for.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly Sir, I have made it my buſineſs to obſerve their humours ſeverally; the one I find to be of a tractable Genius, he'll make a—

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Good Guide for the Blind.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: The other's of a more acid, cholerick temper; I deſign him for a—

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Yard or an Orchard.

div.stage: Aſide. Enter Jef. pulling in an ugly Tyke.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Wuh you clumſie Block-head you, cou'd not you make your entry with more decency than this?—Is that all the reſpect you give to your betters?

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Reſpect! Ay, and too much for a worthleſs Tyke that deſerves not a Cruſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You know Sirrah your Ignorance excuſeth you;—a Tyke!

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ay, and as contemptible an one as ever dy'd of a crooked Pin.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Well, ha' but a little patience, and I'll convince you preſently,—Jeffry provoke him.

div.stage: Jeffry pincheth his ear, the Cur yells.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Now Captain, what think you on't, did not you perceive a choice accent in his exclamation?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ha, ha, nothing but the yelp of a pinch'd Cur.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſorry for you,—you hear ſtill I perceive with a groſs unrefind ſence,—I'll aſſure you, I thought he was ſomething Articulate;—but he's out a' humour now;—Jefry attend him in.

div.stage: Ex. Jeffry with the Dog. Re-enters.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I wonder Sir Cred. a man of your contrivance, ſhou'd ſo much debaſe your noble Faculties;—Why don't you attempt ſome glorious Enterprize, and die a Heroe?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly I am at preſent upon a Project which will be of greater uſe to the City than the Ditch; but moſt of all to the Inſurers;—And that is this—I have devis'd an Engine to blow up the Thames, and ſo prevent all Popiſh Conſpiracies by Water, for you know they have done their worſt already by Fire.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: the Watermen will abuſe you then.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: No, no, I'll prevent that,—I can convey it back in an inſtant by the Penny-Poſt.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Shaw that's an ignoble deſign; contrive rather the good of the whole Republick.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Think you ſo?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ay, ay,—Erect ſome Gymnaſium where Youth may be taught the Art of Addreſſing and Decoying young Virgins at twelve without being beholding to the Inſtiuctions of a good natur'd Mother, to Swear genteely, without frequenting Gaming Houſes; to profane daringly without keeping the Wits Company;—and to be experienc't in all the modiſh ſins of the Age without going to Court.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You propound Impoſſibilities Captain.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Not ſo Impoſſible as your project upon the Thames.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Make me but Iniquity Maſter General and I'll undertake it; and as the Age goes with ſucceſs I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p:
Nay more;—I'll encourage it ſo far as to give 2 or 3
Mannors towards its endowment: But we'll diſcourſe farther on't at Dinner; I dont much care if I Dine with you▪to Day.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Sir you'll do me Honour.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Marry Gad a Mercy—That was the Gymnaſium he was con •••… all this time.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Well honeſt Jeffry; how do's Sir Credulous do?

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: What ſtore of Viſitants he has againſt Dinner time.
Why he's in a ſit of Melancholy, and has order'd that no body ſhall have acceſs to him.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I am a particular Friend man;—I'll go and divert him, he has not Din'd I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: But if that wo'nt prevent you, this will—
From you Sir 'tis poſſible he may admit of a Viſit, ſince there's only two Gentlemen with him; one of'em's a Draper, the ſame that ſent his Man to you Yeſterday with a Note.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: That Soliciting Rogue!—A Pox of his importunity—But why may not this ſame Youth ſmell my buſineſs?
I'll urge it farther—
Go tell the Gentleman I deſire a word with him.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Ha!—He's at Dinner Sir, I muſt not diſturb him.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: At Dinner before Eleven! Ho Sir, you are a fine Fellow indeed;—Are you ſo quick at turning away Buſineſs?—Tis a piece of frugality your Maſter won't thank you for.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: In good earneſt Mr. Shuffle, there's ſo many, and ſuch clearing Stomachs at his Table every Day, that thô there was as much variety as in Heliagabalus's Feaſt, 'tis peice meal't into as many reverſions as an Alms-basket,—Pray Sir, help me for your own ſake, as well as mine, only to repel ſome conſtant Intruders, and then much good may do you.
sp.stage: Enter two Bullies, as to one another.
sp.p: 1. Y'gad Jack here lives the Hoſpitable Knight.
2. Sweet-heart, how does my worthy Friend your Generous Maſter;—He's within, is not he?

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if your buſineſs be urgent, you may find him at the Swan on Fiſh-ſtreet-hill;—he waits upon a Country Lady there, that longs for a Codſhead.
1. 'Sbud what does he mean?—He invited us this Morning.
2. Ay, and made us ſwear not to fail him.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He ne need not have put that conſtraint upon you.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if it be any buſineſs that I can do, I am ready to ſerve you.
1. No, no, we'll wait upon him at another convenience.
sp.stage: Shuf. and Jef. diſcourſe together, 2 Bullies apart from one another.
sp.p: 2. 'Slife Tom, it coſt me two pence (all the ſtock I had) at the Coffee-houſe i'th Morning,—I went to read the News, a purpoſe to provide my ſelf of lies and hard words for him.
1. And I took a whetting turn ith' Walks about ten for a preparative;—a plague o'their diſappointments.
2. S'hart, we had better have accepted Harry's Invitation;—but who wou'd have imagin'd this?
1. Come, let's to the Change, we'll pick up ſome body.

div.stage: Jef. crys after them as they are going out.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Gentlemen, won't you be pleas'd to leave your Names?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I'll engage they have as many as the Grand Seignior has Titles.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Or as an addreſs of a whole County.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I deſire to ſpeak with Sir Credulous Tinklett if he be at leiſure.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: What nature, Pray Sir, is your buſineſs of?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I have ſome Stones of value for him;—but I muſt deliver 'em to his own perſon.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I remember Sir, he was telling he expected you, and commanded me to take theſe trifling concerns (as he call'd 'em from you;—and to deſire you to wait his approbation.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: Here Sir, I'm ſure they'll pleaſe him.

div.stage: Shuf. takes the box, goes out, and re-enters.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Sir, he deſires you to walk in, he'll diſpatch you preſently;—he has ſent to a Lapidary to have 'em try'd.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.p: I left a Cuſtomers in my Shop;—but I'll attend his honour in a Trice.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: A very fortunate riddance; ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Only ſome tranſparent Glaſs-bobs, that the Counterfeit Raſcal has left in my poſſeſſion;—he'll as ſoon peep through a Pillory, as come here again.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: He wou'd ha' put theſe Toys upon Sir Credulous for real ones, I'll warrant, if you had not prevented him.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: No doubt on't,—Come Jeffry we have made our Poſt good long enough.

div.head: SCENE III. Gulman's Lodging.

sp.speaker: Gull.

lg.l: In vain I ſtrive to call paſt Nature back,
The Youthful Dye that glow'd in either Cheek.
And forc't ſo many melting Sighs and Vows,
Is gone beyond the reach of Female Arts:
My Glaſs, that kind Indulgence of my fears,
Now do's forbear to ſooth my willing faith,
And lays its pleaſing flattery aſide;
Fool that I was to credit Lovers Oaths,
And put my choiceſt ſweets into their hands
Without conſideration for th' exchange;
But ſtill I've one reſerve, providing time
Has for the loſs of beauty, ge'en me wit,
And ſure 'tis time to uſe it.—

sp.p: I hope you have had ſucceſs by your ſtay.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Such ſucceſs Madam, as you foretold before I went.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Truly I doubted it;—was he in a ſullen humour?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Ay, as peeviſh as if his Wife had ſtay'd out late laſt Night;—There's a Broker, it ſeems, he has ſome concerns with, is run away.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —But did you whiſper him as I order'd you?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Yes, I told him you were juſt upon Marriage with Sir Populer, and if he did not give you credit for the Silks; things wou'd look a little ſuſpiciouſly.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —And did you offer him ſuch advantages as I directed you?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Yes Madam, I urg'd every thing I thought might be effectual; I told him the ſafeſt way to ſecure his arrears, wou'd be to venture once more upon you.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: And what anſwer'd he?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Upon that, he examin'd his Shop-book, and ſhow'd me your Accounts, the Total Sum I did not much obſerve, nor the Particulars; only the File of Items, which was as deep as a Flight of Wild-Geeſe.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —That baſe unreaſonable Creature; has the Conſcience then to put me down for the Neceſſaries I had from his Shop?—Thou know'ſt Wench, how unuſually civil I was always to him, when I kept a convenient Houſe.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am ſure Madam, he had 'em always freſh out o' the Countrey▪ without paying for a Maiden-head;—he was ſo nice always, I am ſure a Lord has been glad of his refuſe e'r now:—But you may ſee—

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: 'Tis e'en true, a paſt kindneſs now-a days is as little regarded, as a future promiſe; but what cou'd the ungrateful Wretch ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: After he had clos'd the Book, he broke out into paſſion, and ſwore he cou'd not wonder at your impudence, becauſe you were ſo and ſo: But before the damn'd Bawd was any more Tawdry at his charge, he won'd ſee her Ca • ted;—nay, he ſwagger'd worſe then when he miſt his Ring at our Houſe.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: At his charge baſe man!—It ſeems he looks upon the debt as deſperate;—as I am a ſinner, I fear he'll noiſe it abroad and betray me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Never fear it,—though he has little good-meaning for you, yet the hopes he has of a change of your condition, will prevent him.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: How muſt we do in this caſe Wench?—Let me die in a Ditch, if I be not as much at my wit's end, as I have been e'er now to direct a young unmanag'd ſinner.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Never deſpair Madam, I have ſome comfort for you;—Don't you remember his eldeſt Prentice?—The ſame that rally'd ſo at our door one Sunday Night for entrance, when all our Beds and Couches were in uſe.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Yes, and ſwore he wou'd have the Houſe pull'd down the Shrove-Tueſday after;—But what of him?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I perceiv'd as I was i'th Shop, how diligently he watch'd the caſte of mine eye; and now and then I ſeem'd accidentally to throw half a look at him, which he wou'd ſo far improve, as to return me a familiar ſmile,—as who ſhou'd ſay—

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —I obſerv'd this, and willingly forgot my Fan, which he very officiouſly follow'd me out with;—then after a caſt of his Counter-courteſie, he promis'd me, ſuch a trivial thing as my Errand expreſt, ſhou'd not be wanting for my own ſake.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: And there was the cauſe o' your ſtay.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —He had nothing as earneſt towards the bargain.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: When do you expect him?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Exactly at nine—He'll be as punctual as a Tertian Ague.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —You'll know how to pay him.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Ay Madam, I thank your Converſation.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Well, if this ſhou'd unfortunately fail, I muſt e'en betake my ſelf to the poor Whore's laſt refuge, grave honeſt Crape.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Truly Madam, 'tis a very modeſt agreeable dreſs, and eſpecially for one of your deſign; ſince you profeſs as much Religion as a Lady Abbeſs, you muſt be as reſerv'd in your habit too; Sir Populer will miſtake your Neceſſity for your Zeal.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Then I muſt remonſtrate againſt abominable Gauds; as he calls 'em.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —And rail againſt Point, as tedious Vanity.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Againſt Neck laſes and Pendants, as undercent coſtly Trumperies.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Rich Gowns, you muſt call, Popiſh Seducers,

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —And imbroider'd Petticoats, Man-catchers.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Hiſt! Sir Popular.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Take comfort Girl, the good man was very full upon that point the laſt day; you took notice of his Doctrine?

div.stage: ſeeming as if ſhe did not perceive Sir Pop.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Siſter ſpotleſs you are well employ'd, I conceive; there are not many o' your Sex that imitate you now adays;—they'll rather exhort their Women to read a wanton Pamphlet, than a Paragraph of a good Sermon.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Plainly Brother, I was e'en reminding her of her great concern in this World,—we are all Fleſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Ay Siſter, but that conſideration is but little laid to heart in theſe days.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Eſpecially amongſt the Worldlings that are ſet above us.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —Never truſt me, I am weary of this vexatious world, I wiſh I were well diſpos'd out of it.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Offences are given daily, and by thoſe that ſhou'd heal 'em;—The parti-colour'd Prieſts put on their Maſquerading Robes, and tread a French Dance to the ſound of an Organ.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Whilſt the Judges give falſe meaſure, in the Whore of Babylon's Scarlet Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —A Parchment Cloak of blank Deeds wou'd be a more ſeemly Wear for 'em a great deal:—Well, who knows, what they have to anſwer for!

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Then what a pack of debaucht Reprobates are they about court;—They haunt their Neighbours Board, and defile their Beds; and here amongſt the number, if a teaching Brother carries but ſome crumbs of Conſolation, to a Siſter in anguiſh; how uncharitably will they interpret the duty.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: What gaudy Kicſhaws are their Women? In good truth, they're as common, as if the Land were unpeopl'd; and how hideous is their dreſs!—I have e'en reſolv'd to put my ſelf into a plain Primitive Grab; and defie the ſcornful:—Come, Faith my private duty calls upon me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —'Tis about your Prayer time, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: This is the way I have chalkt out to compaſs my deſign; the Widow is Rich and Religious;—Well, my Addreſſes muſt be conſonant with her Severity: I muſt Noſe, Cant, and turn up my Whites, Squint, and counterfeit the reſerv'd Purity of an Hermit, to diguiſe me whilſt I ſue for ſuch a Bleſſing:—In the mean time I muſt play the Patriot with Artifice, and Reſolution; foment Fears and Jealouſies, diſperce Sedition, blind and baffle my unthinking Followers, and be concern'd only for the Religion of my Intereſt;—This is the taking ſure way of repairing decay'd Reputations.

lg.l: Say what you will; a thriving Zeal is beſt
To ſerve the City God of Intereſt.

div.head: SCENE, Sir Popular's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Sir Popular, Shuffle, and three Tradeſmen.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I Think we have got fairly by our Paſſive Obedience, forſooth! And yet for all this Court Doctrine we ſhould find but few of the Sticklers but upon Tryal would hang an Arſe to die Martyrs for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Alas, 'tis too ſure, to our irreparable damage I fear;—We are undermin'd my Friends and Neighbours;—Popery and Slavery lurk under ground to blow up our Lives and Liberties,—Our great Senate, that like a firm Bank, brav'd the Impetuous Flood, and confin'd it to its Channels, is remov'd; and now England, diſtreſſed England, is at the mercy of a threatning Deluge;—How ſoon it may break in upon us, we cannot tell;—The great Miniſters, are Mercenary Penſioners; and Creatures to the French Intereſt; The Favourites are the high-flown Torys, a ſwarm of Inſects bred of the malignancy of a corrupting Nation, and the few juſt men are ſtigmatiz'd with aſperſions; Witneſſes are manag'd, Courts of Juſtice are influenc'd, and though Impoſts are but few for the preſent, I'll warrant they'll play us an after-Game with a witneſs, and Trade and Commerce is decay'd:—In brief, there's ſuch traducing, ſhaming, tampering, and conſpiring, that I never go to Bed, but I expect to riſe with my Throat cut.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: And too great reaſon you have for it,—whilſt I was at the Nine-penny Ordinary t'other day, there came a perſon up to us, in the habit of an Oyſter-wench, with Oyſter-knives as ſharp as Razors.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —Some Jeſuit ſure enough.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay doubtleſs, he lookt ſuſpiciouſly.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: I had notice on't, and order'd the Watch to be doubled;—beſides, the Conſtables was upon their Rounds all Night.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Yet there was a Shooe-maker had the Skin of his Throat ripl'd as he ſlept upon a Bulk.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: The Watch ſav'd his life.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: —Bloody Villains.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: It was buz'd about at Richard's this Morning, that the Papiſts had a private Meeting yeſterdy, at One upon the Exchange, about pulling down the Monument the firſt dark Night, to put the City to the charge of building two other.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: One for the Memorial of the others ruine;—but how was it diſcover'd?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —They were fortunately over-heard, but ſlunk away i' the Crowd.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Curſed Devils!—I had a Letter from a Friend in the Country, that advis'd me to forbear French Wine; it ſeems the Grapes were poiſon'd upon the Vines;—They have got a trick of intoxicating the Air, ſeveral have been before the Chamber of poyſoning for't.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Indeed, I have obſerv'd ſince this laſt Vintage, ſeveral pimpl'd Faces;—But our Engliſh Men—

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Are a people of a robuſt Conſtitution, elſe we had ſeen alterations before this:—You have heard of the miraculous maſſacring Engine, that was found in Devonſhire, by a Juſtice o' Peace that was a ſearching for Armour, han't you?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Only a blind imperfect account on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: 'Twil hurl out above five Miles ſuch a ſort of Wild-fire, as is nouriſht by water, and not to be extinguiſht but by Faſting and Prayer.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Matchleſs wickedneſs!

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —Then 'twill ſling for the ſame diſtance, an inſtrument infallibly mortal, without either piercing or diſcolouring the Skin; ſo that a Crowner knows not how to return the Inqueſt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Barbarous Villany!

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: But the worſt is, it aſſaſſinates the Soul as well as the Body, unleſs one be Spiritually Cap-a-pee'd.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —'Tis more terrible then Totchy Old Time with a ſharp Syth in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: 'Tis charg'd upon occaſion with a large meaſure full of Diſpenſation Powder, and loden with the Caſe—Shot of Equivocation, which the Popiſh Engineer ſo artificially Diſchargeth, that the carnally naked infallibly Periſh.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Horrid Butchery!

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I remember now I have heard on't;—But you miſtake the manner of its diſcovery, Sir Popular.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Very probable, the confuſion o'the times diſorder my Memory.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: It came from beyond Seas in a Letter which expreſt the uſe on't; and was directed to a great Roman Catholick in the Weſt, but through ſcarcity of Paper it broak the vale and appear'd.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Wonderful providence.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: But how little do theſe Conſpiracies awake us? What miraculous ſigns of a Sickly State appear daily? 'Tis not long ſince whole Armies appear'd in the Air, near Durham, and the French Standard diſplay'd.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Not long ſince Anti-chriſt was ſeen Riding upon the Beaſt with the Whore of Babylon behind him.

sp.speaker: Sir. Pop.
sp.p: 'Tis not long ſince Hail-ſtones fell in the Faſhion of Crucifix's and Agnus Dei's.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Nor ſince one o'the Heads upon Weſtminſter-Hall cry'd fire.

div.stage: The Blew-Apron men ſeem diſorder'd all this time.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Not long, ſince the Horſe in the Poultry-Market nicker'd for Provinder.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: But the City would give him none.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Not paſt a Month ſince, the Watch ſaw a Dreadful Comet that hover'd above the Banqueting-Houſe, and ſtream'd out it's Scarlet Tail towards the City.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay; and one of the Life-Guards lighted his Pipe at it. All.—Daring Brute.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p:
—But that which diſmays me the moſt, my Friends, is an Apparition my own Eyes were witneſs of; It was in the likneſs
of an Aged man, Riding upon a Jaded Rainbow; and out of his mouth there proceeded a Label with this Inſcription—O England, prepare, for deſſolation is at hand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Good Heavens!

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Sure the Harbinger had made a long Journey, by the faultring of his Steed.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Yet all theſe preter-natural Omens cannot Alarm a ſelf-ſecure Generation;—How many Suns of late have appear'd in the Heavens? How many Moons of differing Figures and Magnitude have been ſeen at once, to the Diſtraction of Aſtrology?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: How many tall Men and mixt Monſters have been ſhown of late at Bartholomew-Fair; even to the admiration of Men, Women and Children.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Brutus was never more concern'd for the ſinking Liberties of his Fellow Sublects then I am; the Sword of Tyranny like that of Damocles hangs by a ſingle Hair over our Heads, and if we only gaze at the threatning Spectre, without providing againſt the Portent; we may expect the violation of our Lives and Liberties, Rights and Religion;—But now my Friends we'll adjourn, and at our next Convention, we'll propound ſuch meaſures as are moſt conſiſtent with our preſent Calamities.

div.stage: Ex Sir Pop. and the blue-Apron-men. Manet Shuf.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Hiſt! Mr. Zeale, Mr. Zeale.

sp.speaker: Sir,
sp.p: You muſt ſend me a Bever, I am ſo much out upon the Cauſe, I muſt be endebted to you at preſent.

sp.speaker: Zeale,
sp.p: 'Tis the ſame thing Sir, you ſhall have the choice in my Shop.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: And he ſhall have more o' my Cuſtom.—

lg.l: For I, with Citts, as with falſe Dice, will play,
Firſt ſweep enough, then throw the Cheats away.

div.stage: Enter Juliana, as looking upon a Watch.

sp.speaker: Jul.

lg.l: Paſt Three! The long expected Minute's paſt,
Which I with Love's Impatience waited for;
I curſt Time's aged pace, and blam'd my Watch,
Becauſe the Hand ſo faintly ſtole about;
But now the hour that flatter'd my falſe hopes
Is come, and gone; but ſtill my Lover ſtays:
E'en thus the thirſty Traveller, that knew
Once of a cooling Spring, near ſuch a Hill,
Impatient o' the Days tormenting heat,
Thinks ev'ry ſtep a journey, till he comes
To that refreſhing place he uſed of old,
Then eagerly preparing to lie down,
He ſpies the bottom parcht, the Pebbles drie,
Then mutters his complaints, and budgeth on;
Grant he be ſafe—He's here—

sp.p: How ſoon the gaudy Bubble diſappears.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Alone Couſin!—You'v been rapt up in Lovers Paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —I was diſcanting a little, upon a paſſage I have read in a French Novel.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —And you the Heroin;—You are glorying in your Conqueſts over your vanquiſht Admirers.—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You are in your pleaſant vein Couſin.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —I am always in't;—I have no Murther'd Servants to anſwer for, I thank my Complexion; no languiſhing Lover has catcht cold with ſyrenading under my Windows; I was never accuſed in the Myſtical Name of Cloris by the Dying Sonneteer, nor blam'd as an Acceſſary in his Swan-like Dirge;—Nay, I never cauſed the Death of a young Tree, by an Anagramming Penknife, I never—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Receiv'd a preſent of Value from a Servant, and then declared you hate him;—you never gave a Rhithming Lover a Subject to allude upon, and then expoſed his endeavour.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: If a young generous Fop prevents me, and ſwears his Life depends upon my Acceptance; I cannot be ſo barbarouſly ſcornful as to ſee a towardly Fool cut off;—or if an unfortunate pretender muſt needs diſcover his Dullneſs, I am forc't to comply with him, and uſe him accordingly, to be rid of farther importunities.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Now, I am much of another Humour,—I cou'd not receive a Gift from one I diſreſpected; nor laugh at his Poetical Imperfections;—I ſhou'd rather pity him, tho' not many deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Come Couſin, that Sigh betrays you; be free with me;—Has not that Gentleman that makes viſits to you, and you believe to be the only brave Man upon Earth; given you Reaſon to retract your Opinion? Ay, a Conſcious bluſh too,—Well, I perceive your diſorder,—We'll have a Song to divert you,—Here—Lyddy, Sing your new Song.
sp.stage: Calls aloud. Lyddy, Enters, and Sings.

lg.l: See how regardleſs ſhe ſurveys
Whole Crowds of fetter'd Swains,
That boaſt themſelves her Sacrifice,
And Triumph in her Chains.
See while their trembling Hearts expect
Some bleſſing from her Eyes,
She frowns, and with a cold neglect,
Kills all their blooming Joys.
Fair, Mighty Nymph! if you thus haſt
To ſhew your endleſs power;
The number of your Slaves, alas,
Will leſſen ev'ry hour;
And while you pleaſe your boundleſs Will,
Your Empire will decay,
You'll not have lover left to kill,
Nor Subject to obey.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Well Couſin, how do you reliſh the Ayr?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe the Words were the love-task of ſome o' your obſequious Admirers.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Ay, and the Compoſure too;—He excus'd himſelf with the Poets Apology for their dullneſs, haſte; pretending they were his extemporary Thoughts over a Glaſs of Wine, tho one wou'd ſcarce perceiue it by the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, Yonder's a Gentleman deſires to kiſs your Hand; I ſhow'd him into the Dining-Room, and left him rubbing his Sword.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: 'Tis that Fierce, Vapouring, Coward, Bravado, I fancy; and I had as ſoon receive a Viſitant in the Small-Pox, only 'twill be no diſpoſing of him before my Unkle's return, unleſs I go and contrive ſome way.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: My Joy! [ſalutes her] 'Tis true, I have liv'd ſince I ſaw you laſt, but no otherways than dying Parents, that for the hopes of ſeeing an only Child, and feeling Death come ſtealing on, will ſet their Teeth, contract their Fiſt, recal their palling Spirits, and ſtruggle with appointed time; I have liv'd to ſee you once again, now let me die, I cannot chooſe a dearer place than this.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And wou'd you die without me?—How cou'd I ſurvive you?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Thou Miracle of Women!—You have all the Perfections of your Species, without the Frailties, you have Wit and Diſcretion without Deſign; you are Humble & Eaſie without making your ſelf Familiar, and Modeſt without being Coy; you are conſtant in ſpight of Importunities, and Beautiful though a Fortune; you are—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Since I have ſome Qualities that pleaſe you, I ſhall value my ſelf the more; But Deareſt, why did you ſtay?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: My Heart;—I came as directly at the hour, as Death, before, I was loath,—leaſt Sir Populer ſhould be within, and my Viſit renew his Suſpition.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My Watch then was like my Wiſhes, too forward, I expected you this live-long half-hour, and with as much impatience, as Chymiſts do, for the reſult of ſome Experiment; a Thouſand Fears as great as Love could frame, diſtracted me.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: But how long Madam may we believe, the time will be our own? When returns Sir Popular?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O preſently, within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: We muſt husband it with ſuch caution, as a beſieg'd Town does, their failing Proviſion.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: —Madam, Sir Populer is newly come in, and has ſent to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: The news of Peace never came more unſeaſonably to the Souldier of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —With what reluctancy I obey, let my ſighs demonſtrate;—My Deareſt, you may be ſafe here from the buſie eye of jealouſie; if poſſible, I'll ſteal a viſit to you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: The kindeſt power that ever favour'd love, attend thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The rareſt piece, the whole Creation has produc'd, is gone;—What—cannot I bear one hours abſence? How ſhall I compoſe this unruly Paſſion? When ſhe's for ever doom'd to a Rival's Arms?—The raging Storm of Love heaves in my breaſt, and like the weather-forc'd Marriner that labours to avoid the Shore he wiſheth for. I muſt refuſe, what I eſteem ſo dear; I love her too well to Marry her, my unkind Fortune forbids the Banes; I cou'd not ſee her condition below her worth and quality, and therefore muſt be cruel out of kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Dear Captain Roman, I am thine abundantly.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —You expect I ſhou'd return you the ſame Title back? but how came you here?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: What an impertinent queſtion is that to one of my correſpondence amongſt the Ladies;—Why, pretty Mrs. Charlietta cou'd not be well, till ſhe ſaw me.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —She wanted a Vomit, I ſuppoſe, and thought that the ſight of you might provoke it.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —I proteſt Roman, if I thought you deſign'd it as an Abuſe, I wou'd not take it.—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —If I ſhou'd tell thee thou wert handſom, I ſhou'd abuſe thee indeed.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: By the Life of Hercules, there's ſcarce a Lady of Quality about White-hall, but has my Picture.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —To hang up among their Caeſars o' the French Draught.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: ——What a Devil! your ſo witty—But what de'e think if it be for their Cabinet Contemplations;—I am in Water-Colours I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —'Tis true, thou art well enough for a Foyl,—But what brought thee hither to me?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —My little Genius Charlietta directed me;—Sir Popular ſurpriz'd us—a plague of his interruption.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: You were a bouncing of your lofty Heroick Lyes I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I proteſt to tell you truly I was promiſing pretty largely, there was—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —Some Matrimonial Affair in hand?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Will you not diſcloſe.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —Prithee don't enjoyn me to ſecreſie; I don't deſire you ſhou'd communicate any thing that requires it.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: You have more Honour than to betray a Love Parol I am ſure,—know then I had got her conſent.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: To marry?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: No, but to enjoy the Freedom on't without the Form.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —It cannot be ſure.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: 'Slife there's no holding out where I Beſiege, ſhe Surrendered upon the firſt Summons, our Parley was very ſhort.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I am ſurpris'd, tho', I confeſs, I had but little Knowledge of her;—Well,—There's not above one Virtuous Woman.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: One! That's too many by 'th Exception;—Why who wou'd ha' thought her Couſin Juliana had been common?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —Juliana common!

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —Ay as a Bench in a publick Walk;—We Coacht it out a Town together Yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Raſcal Dog, you Lie, you abuſe her;—but here's her Vindication.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Why,—What's the Matter? I meant like a Friend, I knew you lov'd her, and therefore took this Occaſion to undeceive you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Sirrah, I have ſcarce Patience to wait for a farther Information; yet the Reſpect I have to the quiet of the Houſe, ſhall prevail with me at preſent, but be ſatisfy'd, thou ſhalt ſpeak it to her Face, and as I find occaſion, I'll proceed.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: If ſhe denies it, I have Circumſtances will ſilence her.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Sir, My Couſin ſent me to deſire your Patience, I fear her concerns will force her to be uncivil a little longer.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —That's happy.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —Madam, Your Preſence will teach us to Diſpence with your Couſin's Abſence.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Captain Bravado, this was a Courteſie to entertain this Gentleman with your Company all this time.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Faith Madam, I was never diſobliging, eſpecially when commanded by ſo fair a Lady as your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I fear Sir, your Complaiſance may be Injurious to you.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: No Madam, my Buſineſs is not very extreme; tho' there's an aſſignation waits me; then I have Two or Three Challenges to write and ſend away.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Challenges!

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ay Madam, one is to a Courtier that pretends to Love where I do; another is to a Poet that reflected upon me under one of his Characters; the Third is to an Officer that joſtl'd me in a Crowd, and never begg'd my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Senſible affronts indeed;—but I hope you'll ſtay and Careſs Madam Towers, the Beauty of Hatton-Garden, before you go,—liſt—ſhe's coming up I think—

div.stage: [Enter Juliana, whiſpers Roman, and goes out.]

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: You, Roman, How came you thus acquainted with this ſame Madam Towers? By Jove a pretty Woman.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: What wou'd he mean?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —Why the Lady that whiſper'd you;—I thought I had Lampoon'd all the handſom Women in Town;—I never ſee this before.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Never ſee her, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —No, as I'm a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —It was my Couſin Juliana.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —No!

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —Yes Sirrah, this was the very Lady you made ſo Infamous; this was your Wench at will;—Draw Dog—Draw, thou ſomething leſs than Coward.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: No Courage, Daſtard.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Prythee, don't take this Advantage, my Sword's not in Caſe.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —No Excuſe ſhall give thee Refuge Slave, I'll fetch thee one that is.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Confound his Civility;—I'll go and chooſe one for my ſelf, I thank him.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Was ever Coward thus bafl'd before?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ha!—Is he gone?—Has he abus'd me again this way?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —He was reſolv'd not to be guilty of a ſecond raſhneſs.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —Well, he knows the greeting he muſt have, when we meet.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —He was in haſt to ſend away his Challenges.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —If the fixt opinion I have of Juliana's Vertues cou'd have been ſhaken, I had reſign'd it upon this Raſcal's aſperſion; But Madam, I muſt beg of you not to take notice on't to her, it may trouble her;—my hopes of ſeeing her now, won't invite me to ſtay; her buſineſs I fear is in diſpenſable.—Lady your Servant.

div.stage: (Exit Roman. (Brav. peeps in, and enters as in haste, with drawn Sword.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: S'death, is not the Coward return'd yet?

sp.speaker: Carol▪
sp.p: Yes, but Mr. Roman's newly gone.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: By the Martial Deity it was his ſafeſt courſe, elſe I wou'd have had no more mercy on him, than a tedious Poet has of an Actor's memory.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: O brave!—I wonder you that are ſo bloodily inclin'd ſhou'd have ſo much mercy of your ſelf as to avoid him.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Why de'e think I wou'd truſt him to chooſe a Blade for me;—The very Sword he drew againſt me, was mine in point of Honour; I gave it him thrice upon terms.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Mr. Bravado, I muſt needs tell you, I queſtion your Courage; and nothing but ſome bold piece of Chivalry, can redeem your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Command me Madam an Impoſſibility, and I'll effect it; Shall I fetch you the Sultan's Head out of the midſt of his Janizares? Or the Pope in Effigy from the ſtrength o' the Rabble? Shall I bring you—

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Nothing but that Sword o' yours that Roman wears.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: That Madam, is ſo mean an attempt, 'twill fully my honour; but ſince you command it, to morrow you ſhall ſee it laid at your feet.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Well, remember it;—but I have out-ſtay'd my time I muſt go—

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: That's the only tryal I cannot ſtand; But is—there no contrivance, Madam, can continue you another Lovers minute.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Not now, Sir;—Then you know Sir Popular's concluſions when he ſees a Stranger here.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Can you beſtow me in no place conveniently, till opportunity preſent?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Let me ſee—Ho, I have it,—There ſtands a low Table there ſometimes; now if you'll couch upon your hands and knees, if any ſhou'd chance to come in, they'll miſtake you for it; I'll diſguiſe the deſign with a Carpet;—I know no other way of ſecuring you, till I can wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: The poſture will be a little uneaſie, but the conſideration of ſuch a bleſſing after it, will teach me to endure it.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: You muſt kneel here.

div.stage: (He goes to the ſide of the Stage and kneels.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Here—Boy— (Boy enters) bring the little Perſian Carpet out o' the Dining-Room.

div.stage: Enter Boy with a Carpet, ſhe covers him.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: He becomes a Carpet better than a Sword,—I'll be merry with him, if he be not pre-diſcover'd; ſuch a triumphing Coward cannot be abus'd enough.

div.stage: Exit. Carol. Enter Gullman and Faith. Gullman in a homely Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: How do I look, Wench, ſince I reform'd my Dreſs?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Indeed Madam, as taking, as one of five and fifty can be.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Five and fifty Huzzy; 'tis only five and thirty, I have been no more this twenty years;-—'Tis not ſo long ſince I was in a Lampoon; but Youth wou'd be as inconvenient to one of my deſign, as 'tis to a Beardleſs Candidate for a Biſhoprick.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: By all that's good, that nauſcious old ſinner Mother Gullman;—Is ſhe then Sir Popular's Rich Widow?—Well, this Wind may blow me ſome profit;—I'll pretend I do not know her.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: A Stranger here Forſooth!

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Lady I come in the behalf of Sir Popular Jealous, and do aſſure you, an important occaſion detains him at preſent from kiſſing your fair hands.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: I am ſorry Sir Popular ſhou'd make choice of ſuch an unwelcome Mediator;—Go, go, and repeat your branching Vanities to your fine tawdry Gugaws; you are miſtaken here.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Miſtaken, Madam, that cannot be, you are a Fortune, I want one, and Sir Popular needs none.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —What wou'd this troubleſome young Fellow ſay?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Faith nothing Madam, but I Batchelor take you Widow; Come, come, reclaim a young Extravagant by the ſureſt way, Marriage—There 'tis in ſhort.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: You ſcandalous, vain, paultry Scoundrel, that never bleſs your ſelf but when you ſnees; a ſhilling o' your own, I'll warrant, is as rare to be ſeen with you as an Eclipſe, and you cou'd have the impudence to talk at this rate to me; I wou'd as ſoon marry a Criminal under the Gallows;—ſo take that for your final anſwer.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Now Madam, to return you my ſenſe of your Denial in your own Dialect, you are a mercenary, loathſom, ſuperannuated, ugly Sinner; you have Bawded almoſt ever ſince you left Bulking; one o' your Names is Gullman, I remember your Houſe by a laſting Token; you have more Diſeaſes about you then a whole Campaign in a hot Summer; you are worſe plaiſter'd and patcht up than an old leaky calkt Veſſel;—'Tis high time indeed you ſet up for a Fortune;—I'll draw the Curtain and expoſe you, and will have you ſent to Bridewell immediately.

div.stage: He goes towards the Door, Gullman follows and holds him.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Dear Worthy Sir, for goodneſs ſake, conſider, you'll utterly ruine me; if you do this, I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: There's no way to relieve you but one,

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Any way, dear Sir, rather than that.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Well, the tender regard I have to the extremity of any one's condition, has ſo far wrought upon me, that I am willing to come to a Capitulation with you.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Your Terms, ſweet Sir?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You ſhall give me a Bond for 500 l. to be, due preciſely upon your marriage with Sir Pop.—if he fails you, the Contract ſhall be void.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —But you'll endeavour to promote the Match then for your own private Intereſt, as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —That I will;—You ſhall be repreſented to all advantages I'll promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Provide but the Writings, and I am ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —Siſter Spotleſs, I bid you welcome to this earthly Manſion.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Brother Jealous you have my thanks ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —I conceive, our beloved friend Shuffle, wou'd acquaint you with my buſineſs;—in earneſt, he's a good man.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Plainly, I have great hopes in him; I was recollecting his memory with ſome wholſome Paſſages out of a Manual I have at home.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: I have a ſmall piece in this Room, that was writ by a worthy Elder of Tower-ſtreet, that fled afterwards into New-England;—I'll recommend it to you Siſter.

div.stage: Sir Pop. ſtands upon Bravado's back, and reacheth up.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —'Tis remov'd—I know not where to look it.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —It may be fali'n down about that Seat Brother.

div.stage: Sir Pop. goes to look for't about Bravado, he ſtarts up with the Carpet about him, Sir Popular runs back in confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Good Siſter ſpeak to't,—I am unfit,—I had no Devotion in my Family this Morning.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Alas Brother, I have a mortal averſion to all Spirits but my own.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: In the Name of Goodneſs, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Nothing but your humble Servant Lady,—My Name's Bravado.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: How's this!—Some Popiſh Prieſt, that deſign'd to fire the Houſe—Hoa, hoa, within there.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —Secure this Suſpicious Perſon in the Garret, till I be at leiſure to take his Examination and commit him.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —What Providence was here! We might have been all blown up.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —All their Villanies are detected;—Come Siſter, I'll order him to be brought before the face of Juſtice, and then give him over to condign Puniſhment.

div.head: SCENE, Toper's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Toper with a Bottle in his hand.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Was ever honeſt man thus tormented with a confounded abuſive Wife;—S'bud,—here's one of her Badges grieves me ſo, I am ſcarce able to lift a Glaſs to my head,
but here's my Comforter for all that.
This I was forc't to ſecure with as much caution, as a Sailor does a prohibited Truck:
Ha!—marry if 'twas not for this refocillation, I ſhou'd look as forlorn, as a Bottle half out.
Ah, ah—this Brandy's a friendly creature.
Alac, alac, I am a dying man, my Hour-glaſs is almoſt run out, and ſhe's ſo watchful, 'twill be difficult to repleniſh it.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —My dear old Pitcher, art thou whole yet?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —No, I have almoſt loſt one of my ears;—She checquer'd my Corps like a Cheſs-board for my laſt Bout with you;—A drought choak her for an unreaſonable creature, I han't ſlept over a Pot, nor ſet a Glaſs▪ upon its head this two days, Mun.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Profound abſtinence! There's a mortifying pennance indeed:—By Bacchus I have been at the death of a Sea-Captain, and two Dutch Merchants, ſince you and I breath'd one another at Iſaac's laſt.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: What did you drink?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p:
—True Nants;—I challeng'd 'em at their own Weapons,
by Stingo we had a ſmart Ingagement on't; we pour'd it down like Cataracts, till we were ſo inflam'd, you might have made Slap-dragons in our Mouths.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: O Man, for ſuch a Risk now!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: By Jove, I came to promote it.—Here will be that ſolid trifle Sir Credulous,—the Reckoning will be his.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Alac, alac, I doubt I muſt not go along with you.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Illuſtrious Knight, give me leave to lick your feet.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —I am ſorry Sir, I have never a Cask o' Brandy to bid you welcome with.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Seriouſly Gentlemen, I left a Scene of pleaſant diverſion to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Then Sir we muſt acknowledge our Obligation to be the greater.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Was it ſome Bowl o' Punch Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: No, no, a more delicious entertainment;—it was a Combat betwixt a Fleſh-fly and a Spider; but after ſome diſpute, the vanquiſh't Fly beg'd Quarter with what voice ſhe had; but I left her to the fury of the mercy-leſs Inſect.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —'Twas unkind not to relieve her.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Here, Sir Credulous have at ye.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: —I ſhou'd like an Encounter with that, better than the Spider's skirmiſh with the Fly.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —I muſt crave your pardon Sir, I am not diſpos'd to pledge you, I drink nothing at preſent but the ſimpleſt Spring-water that flows.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —What's this?—Did not you give me your honour that we ſhou'd carouſe it with whole Ciſterns in a hand, and Volleys of Huzzahs at every health.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —But, ſince; I have conſulted the Configurations of the Heavens, and I find that Mercury my little influencing Planet forbids it; he is Retrograde, and till his motion be direct, I muſt forbear.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Prithee Knight don't be ſuperſtitious, or if you muſt, let Bacchus be your Tutelar Power; he deſerves to be a Conſtellation the beſt of all the Pack;—He's the jollieſt Heroe amongſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly Gentlemen, if I had apprehended, you wou'd have deſir'd me to drink; I ſhou'd ſcarce have come.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Sirrah, thou drunken, drouſie Sot, how oft have I charg'd you to forbid this thirſty ſpunging hollow Shurk the houſe;
Let me ſee him within theſe Walls again, and I'll batter thee worſe than I wou'd do an Ale-houſe Windows.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p:
Hey!—but why ſo netl'd good Madam? If I keep him company,
I pay my Club with him; and as for the Civilities I receive from him here, he cannot ſay they are unreturn'd, when I have an opportunity at my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Thou Lodgings! Ay, may be ſuch as the Conſtable provides for thee, when he finds thee drunk;—Thou art like ſome Fatherleſs Libel▪ condemn'd and diſown'd; and no body dare entertain thee for fear of ſcandal; Thou art ſo notorious a Bilker, that White-Fryars refuſeth thee.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: If you were any thing but a—

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: But a what, Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: A paſſionate Woman, you wou'd not uſe this Language to a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: A Gentleman, you pitiful inſignificant Scoundrel; 'Tis a clear Gentleman then I'm ſure, What Lands have you, or ever had, but what you carry upon your Shooes in dirty Weather? What other Tenement, but that craſie Cottage, that Kennel for your Soul? It had dilapidated before this, if that ſteep't Punch-Bowl there, had not repair'd it.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: She's more abuſive than a Bill in Chancery;—Obſerve how I'll bob her.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Sirrah, how came the Parlour Hangings cut, the Chinay broke, the Carpet ſtain'd? Tell me, or Ill uſe you worſe, than the Poſts do, as you reel along.

div.stage: Toper looks ſillily, Sir Cred. ſteals behind her, draws out his Mouſe-box, and bolts out the Mouſe before her face. She ſtarts.—He laughs, ſhe beats him.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What, what's the matter Lady?—I meant you no harm by my troth.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Do ye ſport with me, you babling Buffoon, get you gone amongſt your Play-fellow, and be waggiſh there.—I'll ſcower the Houſe of you all—Out with ye—

div.stage: She turns 'em all out. Amazonia ſola.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Tho' the ſtupid Block-head, has not ſence himſelf to that degree as to be jealous; yet his Companions by their too frequent reſidence here, may be injurious to my unſuſpected pleaſures; but now theſe trifling fears are remov'd, and my kind youthful Gallant may come ſecure from the turn of Interruption:—Though ſuch a Husband may be a Womans grief upon one account, yet the good ill Quality may be uſeful upon another;—When my Lover is not expected, I confine the Sot to his hated Abſtinence; but when his preſence wou'd be troubleſom, I indulge his weakneſs, and the eaſie Fool thankfully withdraws.

div.head: SCENE, A Coffee-Houſe.
div.stage: Scene draws, and preſents Sir Popular's Mechanicks ſeated at a Table, with News before 'em. They diſcourſe ſeriouſly.
div.p: 1. NO, no, we ſhan't have a Parliament this half year, I have a great ſuſpicion of ſome Court practices, let me tell you that.
2.—Ay, there was a Council not long ſince, where 'twas debated about the eſtabliſhing of a ſtanding Army; but the reſult on't I ſhan't know till to morrow.
1. For certain Neighbour?
2. Ay, ay, but too ſure, I had it from the mouth of one o' my Lord Preſident's Grooms.
3. There was a Stranger at my Shop very lately, that told me, the French Ambaſſador had a private Audience about ſome Affairs that nerely concerned the Liberty o' the Subject.
1.—But Providence, I hope, will defeat all their Machinations.
2. Here Boy, bring me the Impartial Proteſtant Mercury.
div.stage: (Boy carries him a Paper. Enter Sir Popular, and Shuffle.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: What News Mr. Fickle?
2. Here's ſome that's material.

From Colcheſter we are inform'd, That on the 22d▪ Inſtant, a certain poor Journey-man Taylor lay intranc'd for ſome days, and cou'd not be reduc'd to the leaſt ſenſe by all the Extremities cou'd be apply'd;—at laſt after ſeveral painful groans, the Organs of his Body begun to be diſpos'd, and he return'd to himſelf; after which, he ſent away for a learned Divine▪ and tender'd him this following account, viz. That ſomething appear'd to him in the likeneſs of an Eagle, with Magna Charta under its Talons; then preſently he heard a voice in theſe words, This is England's Emblem, unleſs it uſe means.—Which Relation was not a little ſurprizing to all True Proteſtants there preſent.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: 'Twas only ſome Surfeit o' Cucombers.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: And Magna Charta under its Talons!—How exactly did the Viſion repreſent Tyranny cowering over Liberty.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —How deſolate with thou be, to ſee the Honourable Court of Aldermen ſlaviſhly whipt with their own Faſces!
•••••… hen our Cheſts will be rifl'd, our Goods and Chattels diſtrain'd, 〈…〉 , and ſo be hang'd at our own expence.
〈…〉 Conventicles muſt be turn'd into Quires, our grave formal 〈…〉 fly Copes, whilſt Hopkins and Sternhold blow the Bellows 〈…〉 the Organs.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Our Matrons will be Raviſht, our Daughters Deflowr'd, our Children brought up in profane Toryiſm.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: The face o' the times ſeem to threaten all this, and ſtill we put the danger far from us.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: I wiſh the Divination of a Strowling Gypſie prove not too fatally conſequent.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Do ye mean the Propheſie in Seventy Eight?

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: No, another ſince, but altogether to the ſame purpoſe; only in different Words and Poſtures;—This laſt, ſtar'd and rav'd and foam'd, and then howl'd out in a dreadful Tone, the Dragon of Bow, will devour the Graſhopper of the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Trade you ſee muſt truckle to Superſtition.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: The ſigns on the Change, to the ſign of the Croſs.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Lawful Gain, to Peter-pence.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —The Frock, to the Sirplice.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —The Shop-Book, to the Maſs-Book.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: And a good bargain of Wares to—

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —An ill one of Errors.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —But ſince there's means, my Friends and Neighbours, let us be reſolute; ſhall we be trampl'd upon like Worms, when we may reſiſt like Lyons? Let us Petition, Proteſt, Remonſtrate, Covenant, and Aſſociate againſt the Common Enemy; let us ſet apart a day of Humiliation for a Bleſſing upon our undertakings; let none of us grudge our Chriſtian Contribution to relieve our diſtreſt Religion; it lies bleeding, and her gaping Wounds cry loud for Oyl, whilſt we only look on and pitty; let us make a Publick Bank, and liſt our ſelves under St. Michael, to go out againſt the Dragon and his Angels.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

div.stage: They call for Coffee, the Boy fills the Diſhes and placeth them; they take 'em off, Sir Pop. ſays Grace to himſelf, before he drinks, and after

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Come, my Friends, our preſent Concerns deſire more privacy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Kindly-Welcome Gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter Sir Credulous, Toper, and Fluſh. [They ſeat themſelves.]

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Dam theſe dull drouſie Coffee-Houſes; I hate 'em;—None but your doſing Dunces of buſineſs come in 'em;—I had as ſoon be ſeen in a Church as here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p:
O Sir, theſe are of great convenience to a Republick, I'll aſſure
you; for beſide the incomparable virtue of the Berry, you may know •… here daily how the Pulſe of the State beats.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Pray don't tell me o' your State Symptoms, if it be diſcompos'd▪ I cannot retrieve it, unleſs a healing Draught, my own preſcription, will do it.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ay, that's the only Reſtorative when all's done.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: And we ſhall ha' work for't preſently: we are ſo nigh your houſe, we ſhall have all the Mum-Glaſſes, and Coffee-pots about our ears quickly.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What do you mean by that Mr. Fluſh?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Why, I fear the Inquiſition of Toper's Helliſh Wife, that piece of eager Wine upon the Fret.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I frequent Coffee-Houſes ſo ſeldom, ſhe'll never ſuſpect I am here man.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Mr. Toper, I can ſecure you three days to your own diſpoſal, without interruption from her.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Marry, Heavens bleſs you Worthy Sir, but how?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I'll adminiſter a certain thing of the nature of an Opiate, but made up of the choiceſt Ingredients the four Elements cou'd afford.—'Tis compounded of the Animal Spirits of a Dormouſe, and ſeveral invaluable Simples refin'd by extraction; one Scruple provokes a dead ſleep without intermiſſion for three days.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: For pity ſake, give her one Thouſand, I'll pay for 'um with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Alas Sir, the Treaſures of the Eaſt wou'd not do it, yet however out o' revenge to her, and good will to you, I'll prepare a Semi-ſcruple more.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: And I'll drink your Health as long as I can ſtand.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: What a parcel of Improbabilities lie ſcatter'd about here?—What's this?—The Domeſtick Intelligence?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: O let's hear that by all means; it inſiſts upon the Revolutions of our own Country—Let's hear if—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: The Engliſh Genius be as pregnant at invention, as the Foreign;—Well—.
Yarmouth, Nov. the 6th. This day a Veſſel laden with Clare • s, was forc't upon the Sands, and was ſlav'd, before ſhe cou'd be got off; but all her Crew came ſafe a-ſhoar.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Marry, I ſhou'd ha' lik'd the News better if the men had been loſt, and the Wine ſav'd.—A Murrin take the Storm.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —By the next • umper, if I had been aboard, I wou'd have imbrac'd a ſinking Hogſhead, and gone to the bottom merrily.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: O mun, the Tritons had a bleſſed time on't.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Ay, there was roaring doings amongſt 'um;—Sure 'twas a Jovial ſight, to ſee old Neptune pierce a Veſſel with his Trident, and all the watery Court drinking round in full Shells.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Then reeling along and breaking their Heads againſt the Rocks.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Seriou • ly, 'twou'd be raviſhing to hear the frolick Syrens ſing, Down the Red Lane.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —And to ſee the ſociable Souls knock upon a wrackt Hull for more Liquor.—Oh!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: And the Green-ſickneſs Nymphs ſimpering at full ones,—Puny Sluts.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —'Twas always my Hypotheſis, that the Reflux was caus'd by their drinking, and the Flux by their diſemboagning.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —And a very reaſonable ſuppoſition too.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Indeed Gentlemen, I have ſpent ſome years ſtudy in ſearching into the Oeconomy of that Element, but not with the ſatisfaction my curioſity requires; I am now thinking to deſcend in a Vehicle of Glaſs, and ſo p • y into that Conſtitution, I ſhall be taken for ſome Chryſtalline Rock.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Poo—this only loſeth time. Boy—A Glaſs o' Mum.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Jackanapes—why no fuller? Here's not above two Gulps.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: —'Tis right Brumſwick, indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Pray Sir ſhow me that Intelligence you had in your hand.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —No, no, we ſhall be too late.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter then;—I had only a little occaſion to look amongſt the Advertiſements.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Have you found ſome Spaniel, or ſtray'd Horſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —No, but I have loſt an elaborate Thought; if any o' the Poets find it, I ſhall never have it again.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Never fear it Sir Credulous, they commonly publiſh all they have, and more too a great many times.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Mine are remarkable, I ſhall diſtinguiſh it,—But are you not for a Diſh of Coffee?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No, no, I hate to have a puddle o' your Outlandiſh Nuſance cloging my Stomack.

sp.speaker: Top,
sp.p: Puh.—a ſcouring Bottle of Pontack will ſcour it again, Mun.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Nuſance! Take it from me, its Vertues are unknown;—But what ſay you to a Glaſs of Mum.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Loathſom, ropy ſtuff; the tir'd Citizen's recruit: I need none of their Artificial Provocations▪

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, qualifie a Diſh of Coffee with an allay of Tea.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Faith let's be for Harry's now, I am for honeſt Trinkelo, I han't had my ſtowage this two days.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Come Sir Credulous, now for a ſprightly Cup.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Wellcome Gentlemen.

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Popular's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: But wou'd not Sir Popular be very ſevere with you if he was inform'd who you were?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ay, as the Prentices are upon a Pillory'd Papiſt; there was a pious Baggage with him, did help to exaſperate him the more.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I am ſorry for your misfortune.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Let me be hang'd, if I was not baited by a rack o'Slaves, worſe than a Pick-pocket; they lug'd me about, and ſtript me; and accus'd me of a deſign to fire the Houſe, and that my Snuſh box was a Granado.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: But cou'd not the Boy that admitted you, reſolve the doubt?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: When I alledg'd, I had ſeveral honourable Viſits to your Ladiſhip the little heedleſs Lace-coat ſaid, he had never ſeen me here.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: That forgetful Jack!

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —But when the Conſtables came with their painted Authority in their hands, one of 'em knew me, and confirm'd what I had ſaid before in relation to my ſelf; then Sir Popular beg'd my pardon, and promis'd me his aſſiſtance in the promotion o' the Match; which, Madam, I hope you'll pleaſe to bleſs with your conſent.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: As ſoon as you preſent me with Roman's Sword.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Alas Madam, 'tis too degenerous a Trophy, only your Commands will gloſs it.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Well Sir, I hope the next time I ſee you, to ſee the Sword in your hand.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I Proteſt Madam, to tell you truth, I do a little diſpair of diſarming the Coward to day; my Engagements are ſo obliging, I fear I can ſcarce neglect 'em to correct his late inſolence.—But—

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Theſe Men of Honour are always ſo taken up;—'Tis ſome dwelling buſineſs I fancy.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ay, by your fair ſelf, and with both Sexes, let me periſh.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —You are a Man o' buſineſs, Mr. Bravado.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —My Lady Love-all

ſent to me to be at my Lodgings about three; her Coach, it ſeems, muſt ſtop there; I had no ſooner read her Billet, but I had another to unknot from my Lord Scruple, a tickliſh reſenting Puppy;—I muſt ſecond him i'th' Morning.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I never thought my Lord had been quarrelſom.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: No more he is; he has ill nature enough, but he wants Courage, hang him, I have been very ſmart on his Livery, have banter'd his Coach and Horſes, ridicul'd the conceit of his Dreſs, check'd the rudeneſs of his Careſſes, corrected the harſhneſs of his French, the darkneſs of his Stanzas; and from me all this ſeem'd like privilege.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: 'Tis like Sir, you might claim a particular freedom, as his Familiar.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: No Faith, I paſt all ths upon him at Longs's the firſt time I ſaw him; though if one, he ſuſpected wou'd not fight, had but miſplac't the leaſt Tittle, he wou'd have improv'd it to a breach of Civility, and then ha' grown Captious.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: So much for my Lord; now for my Lady Love-all; if I miſtake her not, ſhe's none o' the moſt correct Pieces.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: As diſorderly a Maukin as ever was beholden to art;—She has a caſt of an eye, which I perſwade her is a wanton, delicious Ogling; then her Lips are bloated, which ſhe calls full and pouting; and her Chin is reflext, but ſhe complements the deformity as a dimple; then her complexion is a kind of a Hue made up of all colours, and changeable according to the poſition of the eye.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: So,—your deſcription is copious enough a'ready; yet it ſeems you can diſpence with all theſe Errata's.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I proteſt her Paſſion is ſo unmanageable, ſhe'll admit of no repulſe. Nay, ſhe'll betray it in publick; She's now working me a Suit o' Lace which ſhe expects I'll wear.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: 'Twere pitty Sir to diſappoint ſo kind a Creature, which I am afraid you muſt do, if your ſtay here be any longer;—I wou'd not detain you another Minute for all the Joys you carry along with you;—Therefore, pray, if you muſt be formal, take your leave.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: If the Queen of Love ſhou'd come to court me, to the full poſſeſſion of her ſtore, I wou'd refuſe the ſueing Charmer for one Kiſs of that inviting Hand: Ay, tho' my Principle was in the Field, and ſtripping to encounter; I am ſure I ſhou'd ſtruggle with my honour, before I cou'd leave you.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Fie Sir, this is too ſoft, this Spirit will never diſarm Roman.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I cou'd as ſoon be kick't, and—

div.stage: Enter Roman as reading a Letter: Bravado ſlinks out at the Door.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Mr. Bravado, What are you gone?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —How! Was that ſparkiſh thing here, and gone?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Ay, and in all the haſte that a Coward can make from the purſuit of danger;—I'm beholden to you Sir, elſe it wou'd ha' been as difficult to ha' remov'd him, as 'tis to ſeparate an old Stateſman and his Opinion.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —I am ſorry Madam, I was not inſtrumental to your delivery a little ſooner.

sp.speaker: Carol.
