sp.p: Truly his Company was as inſupportable, as a noiſe of Beggars is to a Miſer; firſt he tortur'd me with an endleſs diſplay of Proweſs; then made a Digreſſion to the Women, how paſſionate ſome perſon of Honour was for him; and—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I fear he'll ſcarce make me a Conſident to his Amorous Atchievements any more.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: No,—you did not acquit your Truſt with that Fidelity was requiſite; but he reſolves to correct you for't—I have appointed him proportionably a harder Task than ever Hercules undertook.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Is it to diſcharge a Pot-gun without winking.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p:
No, 'tis only to make me a Preſent; I conceit I cou'd weild a
Sword well, and ſhou'd fancy yours in particular; but I have made a Vow to receive it from no hand but his.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: He'll ſooner venture to ſnatch one out o' the hand of Juſtice.—But where's your Couſin Madam?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Gone to the New-Exchange Sir,—Did not her Boy give you a Letter?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Yes, but it did not take notice where ſhe was; only, that her return wou'd be within leſs than an hour.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: In the mean time Sir, if you pleaſe to divert your ſelf with a Hiſtory, I'll fetch you Sir Walter Rawleigh; I have a little trifling concern that calls me away.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: No,—I'll go and diſpatch half an hours buſineſs, and be here again,—Madam your Servant.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —How agreeable this Gentleman's behaviour is in compariſon of Bravado's; his modeſt and equal Deportment ſteals on inſenſibly, and wins upon our Sex; whilſt the other thinks his modiſh lewdneſs is moſt prevailing; and thus provokes hate with that very Quality he thinks incites Love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Has Mr. Roman been here yet Couſin?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Yes, and newly gone.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Gone!—It is not Three; I am ſure the Chair-men pac't away at a conſiderable rate, but did not he excuſe his haſte?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Only with a Promiſe he wou'd be here again about half an hour hence;—But I'll leave you Couſin to be paſſionately elegant upon your Lover's abſence.

lg.l: —And ſure our thoughts tow'r with the nobleſt flights,
When pinion'd with the ſofteſt Plumes of Love;
What Pageantrys of fond Immortal Joys,
And what vain ſenceleſs fears we apprehend1
Tyrannick Paſſion blindly curbs our Souls,
And ſubjects all our reaſon to its Laws;
Whilſt ſlaviſhly we own its Sovereign right
Eſteeming ſuch bright Chains as Ornaments.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, a Footman in a Blue Livery ſeam'd with red, gave me this Letter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis from Mr. Roman, Pray Heavens the Incloſure prove as welcom; I open it with as much awful dread, as a modeſt Penitent does his heart to his Confeſſor.

—Nor was my fears, thin ſhallow Phantoms;—Alas ſome ill natur'd buſineſs has detain'd him; and we muſt be divorc't a whole day more;—A Day!—It muſt not be—I can't be rackt with the Convulſions of hope and fear ſo long;—I'll write with
all the feeling Thought, Pathetick Love candictate.—But ſure he'll come, twas only ſome deſign to heighten my ſurprize.—But if he ſhou'd not—Yes he will—my confuſion of thought diſtracts me;—I make needleſs Objections, and return as wild Anſwers;—Well—my reſtleſs paſſion has almoſt wrought it ſelf into a calm;—my Spirits grow dull, my Eye-lids heavy, and all my Faculties indiſpos'd;—I'll endeavour to ſettle my diſorders with a Slumber.

div.stage: (She ſits down, and leans back as ſleeping. Enter Sir Popular, Sir Credulous, and Jeffry.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ha! Seriouſly the Lady's Organs are untun'd;—but don't diſturb her.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Pray let me conceive your reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You ſhall know it preſently—Jeffry here take this Key,—go into my Repoſitory, and fetch me the Paper with the black Seal upon't.

div.stage: Jeffry takes the Key and goes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: I hope you intend no harm here, Sir Credulous,

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —No, no,—I have only ſent for a certain Philter, which was found out after many years travel, and long experience, by that Aeſculapius of his▪ Age, Don Arnando Curioſo the Spaniſh Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: The Virtues of it?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —They are innumerable Sir,—if you be Frenchify'd, it cures you beyond Mercury, without Salivation or Bagneo, if you be ſcorbutick, it carries off the malignity by its operation Diuretick,—if▪ you be Hypocondriacal, it—

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —Here's a hippo-conjuring with you;—Do you make my Houſe an Hoſpital? This was not the buſineſs of your viſit, I conceive, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But its greateſt vertue is—

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —Pray no more of its Vices, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I tell you Sir, 'tis of ſo ſubtle and inſinuating a nature, that by its Incorporation with the air, it ſmites upon the Olfatick Organ, and produceth the effect of Love; 'twill be requiſite to my deſign with your Neece.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Moſt requiſite indeed.

div.stage: Enter Jeffry gives him a Paper.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Sir Popular take care to hold your Noſe upon the op'ning of this Paper, or your Paſſion may be greater for me then becomes your Sex; Jeffrey, do you make uſe of the ſame precaution.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Not I Sir, none can love a good Maſter too well.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: An honeſt Servant.

div.stage: Sir Cred. unties the Paper. Sir Pop. ges up to him, and ſpeaks through the Noſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: In earneſt, 'tis like your ordinary Damask Powder.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: It reſembles it indeed.

div.stage: Sir Cred. holds it under Juliana's Noſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: 'Tis no ſuch ſubtile Body, Sir Credulous

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —You muſt know Sir, there are certain minut • Volatile Particles afloat amongſt the groſſer; and from theſe proceeds this Philo-poietick quality.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: His Trumperies are like the French flim-flams, valuable only becauſe of their hard Names.

div.stage: (Aſide.) Sir Cred. ties up the Stuff.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Here Jeffry,—carry it ſafely back.—But hark you Sirrah, has no odd Commotions ſollicited you?

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.p: Y'faith Sir, Methinks you look exceeding lovely; ah that Eye, that Chin, that Forehead; y'faith Lady Maſter if you were but a Woman, I know what I know—ah,

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Get you gone, get you gone, you Knave you;—did not I give you warning o' this.

div.stage: (Ex. Jeff. bowing and kiſſing his hand towards Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Now, Sir Popular, you may inlarge your impriſon'd ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: What a wonderful effect it has wrought upon the poor Creature, I perceive there's no reſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You may as ſoon unravel your Deſtiny.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Now Sir, ſince your Marriage with my Neece is unqueſtionable, I conceive, you'll conſider how active and induſtrious I have been; her Fortunes are exactly as I acquainted you; and thereupon I muſt preſume to tell you, I have a Suit to you

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I won't part with an Atom of my Powder before hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Under favour Sir, d •… believe my requeſt to be ſo unreaſonable;—'Tis only to lend the Good Old Cauſe one Thouſand Pound before the Conſummation of your Conjugal 〈◊〉 , and another Thouſand after.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: What, then is your Brotherhood's Treaſury exhauſted?

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —'Tis only lent for the better confirmation of our Laws and Liberties; and muſt be to be expended in the maintenance of the Cauſe aforeſaid; I am commiſſion'd Receiver, and will take care your Talent ſhall be improv'd; in earneſt I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Soft;—She awakes.—

div.stage: Juliana as ignorant of their preſence.

lg.l: Why did the dear deluſion fleet away,
And ſo abruptly cloſe its flat'ring Scene?
How pleaſingly tranſported have I been
With ſhort and kind abuſing Extaſies?
I thought I tumbl'd on a Moſſy Pallet,
Cloſe by a Stream that gently ſtole away,
And hum'd with ſoft confuſion as it run
Amongſt the ruſtling Pebbles, and along
The verdant Banks, grew Rows of ſtouping Vines:
Up ſtarts a Sylvan from a Covert buſh,
Untwines the circling Branches till they bled,
And brought the ſwelling Cluſters to my hand,
Then after ſome Grimaces, trip't away.
One Grape far more tranſparent than the reſt
I cull'd, and ſporting with it, dropt it in,
Then catching at it ſuddenly, methought
I ſlip't, and ſo awak't with the affright.
Still, ſtill—

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Neice, Neice, I muſt not ſuffer you to chooſe a Grape for your ſelf, I have provided one here for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Lady, I was the Grape you were ſo concern'd for, and am ſafe;—through this tranſparency you may read my paſſion.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Pray Sir don't inſult over an innocent ſurprize.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: 'Twill be convenient Sir Popular▪ that you moralize the Sylvan and withdraw; I perceive the Operation already; therefore your Preſence and the Lady's Modeſty may be a little diſonant.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: In earneſt, you provide diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Now fair Angel, let not an Abſtemious Baſhfulneſs reſtrain your Deſires; Come and pour out your Love-ſick Soul into my Breaſt,—I'll cheriſh it, and reſtore it whole again.

div.stage: (Goes to her to Salute her, ſhe throws from him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Infect not me with your Peſtilent Breath; I loath your Embraces.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Shaw, this is the ſtrangeſt humour: Come, I'm confident you love me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Enjoy your belief then.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Well.—She ſhall never taſte the Joys ſhe has refus'd, I'll puniſh this coyneſs with diſdain, till her Tears petrifie her; then ſhe ſhall ſtand as a Monument for baſhful Maids.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Sir, if I have intruded upon your Secreſie; I expected my Couſin had been here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Don't retreat my Pretty Creature, bleſs me only till I have given you an account of that unhappy Creature.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Unhappy! No ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir▪ Cred.
sp.p: She might ha' been otherwiſe, only ſhe neglected it;—in Fine, Madam, ſhe loves me.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: In troth▪ as great an unhappineſs as cou'd befal her.
But I hope Sir, you are not ſo cruel as to ſee her Virgin Bloſſoms ſnatch't by Death; ſince you can prevent the Tyrant's long reach.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But if I do; I'll be hang'd in her Zone;—She has already diſown'd her Title to my Heart, and never ſhall be admitted to a ſecond Claim.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Truly ſome o' theſe Women are ſo humerous—Now, I never cou'd refuſe in publick, ſomething I long'd for, and then condemn my ſelf for it in private.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Moſt excellent Form, you alone have reconcil'd me to your Sex; There is a ſecret Harmony betwixt our Complexions, and I do here proclaim you Miſtriſs of my Heart.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: What—Sir Credulous here?—You have made uſe o' my Name Knight for your Introduction.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You miſtake Sir; my own challengeth a greater Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: And you have a pretence to that Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I have ſeriouſly; and her goodneſs has encourag'd it.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —Madam will you throw your ſelf away, upon an undiſcerning Idiot, that dotes more upon Tinſel Toys than real perfections? He'll barter your whole Fortunes for a Painted Rattle.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Lady, he's a ſtupid Illiterate Animal; in nothing humane, but only that he laughs and looks up;—You muſt pardon him, he knows not how to value a Rarity.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Why, you Incorrigible Fool, will you miſcal your Trangam Rarities?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I'll appeal to you Lady if theſe be Trangams;—Firſt for Antiquities—I can produce one o' the Trojan Horſe's Shooes; a Black-Jack of a Grecian Officer's Boot-Top; a Pocket-Glaſs of Janus's Spectacles, and ſeveral others. Now for my Novelties—

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Your Antiquities are Cheats, and your Novelties, Traſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Thou art a Moving Clod, and acts only by the Dictates of Heat and Moiſture.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: You are an Hoſpital of lame Arts, and ſickly Sciences.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Thou art a Lyar with a bad Invention.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —Thou art a Title-page to a Treatiſe of Elves and Goblins.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Thou art an Aeſop Fables, without the Morals:

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you talk of Elves and Goblins, wou'd they don't hear you; I'll aſſure you this Room's haunted.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: By Jupiter, if a leering Shadow ſhou'd come in hither, I wou'd make bold to kick its lean Worſhip out again.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I ſcarce think thou haſt bravery enough to encounter Air.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I never heard he durſt draw a Sword.
Come Sir Draw, you ſhall have a fatal proof on't preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Now Sir, I'm for ye.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —Ha;—Wou'd I were well off it again.
'Tis your Armour perhaps that makes you reſolute; we'll ſtrip and fight it fairly.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Indeed Gentlemen, there ſhall be no blood ſhed here;—I'll call in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Now Caitif, I'll mince thee worſe than a City Sempſtreſs does her words.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —And this ſhall maul you more, than a dull Author do's his Original.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred▪
sp.p: Have at your Soul.—

div.stage: [They both flie back, and puſh quick at a diſtance. Enter two Anticks and Dance, Sir Credulous and Bravado run in a Fright to either ſide of the Stage, and ſtand cloſe; The Anticks take their Coats in the Dance, and throw 'em out at either Door, then their Hats, then their Peruques off their Heads, and dance out with 'em. Sir Credulous looks out fearfully.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what a frightful Gambol was this, am I alive, tro.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Are they gone—I am all in a Sweat,—Doubtleſs they were a couple of Devils, that were waiting for us, if we had kill'd one another.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But they were diſappointed for all their cunning;—My hair ſtood ſo erect, I cou'd perceive it move my Wig.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Why, where is it?

div.stage: Sir Cred. lays his hand upon his head.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Good now! 'Tis gone and yours too.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —Mine too! A Plague o' their Pilfering Frolick;—And our Cloaths too, as I live—

div.stage: They look ſimply upon one another. Enter Carol.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: You are like Gladiators indeed now, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I Proteſt Madam, Sir Cred. ows his Life to an Accident, or let me periſh

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: —Was not your Sword ſharp enough?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ha, ha, the Lady was arch upon him there; ha, ha, ſeriouſly the Fancy makes me amends for the loſs of my Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —How!—Your Cloaths gone, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ay, faith Madam,—juſt as I directed the dead-doing point to his Heart, his guardian Devil interrupted the Paſs, ſweep't away our Cloaths, and vaniſh't in a Flaſh o' Fire.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Fair Creature, the odds were mine when the Daemons came;—but the truth on't is, they took their leave a little rudely.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Sir Popular will be here preſently; therefore if you'll walk into my Chamber you may be unſeen there, till you can Careen your ſelves again.

div.head: SCENE I. Shuffle's Lodging.
div.p: HOw ill my Practice and my Principles agree!—My Maiden honour at firſt reſolv'd and ſtrugl'd with unwilling Conflicts, before it yielded; but Poverty importun'd, and Proffers prevail'd;—Now I can cheat a Citizen with a City Conſcience;—Yet ſtill methinks I have ſome remorſe;—But why have I?—Theſe People I deal with, deſerve no better;—They'll lift one hand up to Heaven, and pick Pockets with the other:—A fair Correſpondence with them, loſes its gloſs; and is but Honeſty miſplac't; But—

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: 'Tees ſtrange Sir, yoo ſhould no remember me, meetheenks yoo have no reeſon too complain of me uſage,—Dee Cure was both ſpeedy an perfect:—But yoo dou foorgeet me.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: No, no, my Shins and Shoulders put me in mind of you: I feel the Symptoms on't ſtill; I fear the Lues frets in my Veins ſtill; then, I have Gleetings frequently.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Deſe bee oonly ſome Seminal Waſtings, de which do proceed from your Weekneſs; bot me vill ſend you a Doſe of my Pilulae Retentrices, de which vill obſtruct 'em.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: None o' your ſipper-ſawſes for me any more, good Mr. Doctor, you have tamper'd with me too much already; but my comfortis, No Cure, no Money.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Vell, Vell, bot Begar me vill no abus'd by yoo,—Me vill eder have my Money or yoor Boody.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: A Pox o' your damn'd mincing; why do you clip at this rate to me you Counterfeit Raſcal; do not I know you? Was not I the firſt that advis'd you to melt your words; and paſs for a Forreigner? If it had not been for me, you had only been a Zany ſtill; Did not I witneſs you went out Doctor at Padua, and taught you to counterfeit your Teſtimonial from thence?

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Well, Well, this ſhan't bring you off, I'll tell you ſo much.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Do your worſt you drudging Clyſter-pipe, I'll make you flie the Town, I'll aſſure you; I'll acquaint the College who you are; and how you are in Fee with an Apothecary, to preſcribe coſtly Drugs, and rich Compoſitions; which he only obſerves in the making up of his Bill, but never in his Adminiſtrations.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: You ſhall loſe your ſelf, as you walk along, before I repair you again.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You repair me!—You Suppoſitor; thou art not Phyſician enough to preſcribe a Drench;—Get you gone and rake in diſtreſt Fundaments; hide your Ignorance with hard words; and maul your Latin beyond cure.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant;—Faith I am glad you'r come, I was juſt going to ſend for you.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Honeſt Mr. Shuffle give me your hand;—I was going upon a little buſineſs this way, and thought you wou'd take it ill if I did not call to ſee you;—My Wife gives her ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —It ſeems then this Viſit was deſign'd;—You told her you were coming hither.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: No really not I; ſhe ſurmis'd ſo, but I did not deſign it at that time.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Then the Obligation is leſs o' my ſide:—Come, come, you Gentle Rogue you, you came a' Dunning, did not you? Hang't Man, modeſty and the buſineſs of your Errand are inconſiſtent.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Really Mr. Shuffle you miſtake me, I had no occaſion for Money.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: And that's well; the truth on't is, I have money ready, becauſe I am unwilling to tranſgreſs my promiſe; but ſince your Occaſions are indifferent, 'twill do me a kindneſs; I muſt diſpoſe of it elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: But a—
Well—dee ſee—I am now going.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: ——Nevertalk of going yet Man; here will be my Lord Change preſently; he has turn'd off his old Milliner; I'll recommend you to him; he ſhall go home with you and furniſh himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Your Servant good Sir, I fear I ſhall be too late for an occaſion; beſides, I don't go directly home, I have Concerns by the way.—Here's one at Door Sir—

sp.speaker: Soll.
sp.p: Mr. Shuffle the Money has been due above a Fortnight, and I cou'd hear nothing from you.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: How cou'd you expect it, unleſs it were to contract another Debt with you; doubtleſs you are not ſo unreaſonable as to demand Payment.

sp.speaker: Soll.
sp.p: —You know Sir, I am only an Agent, 'tis another's buſineſs; I am oblig'd to the Duty of my Office.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Prithee don't ſham me with your Duty and your Office; de'e think I am a ſtranger to your ſpecious plauſible Cheats, don't I know how you ſhift and contract in one another's Names.

sp.speaker: Soll.
sp.p: I profeſs to you, the Money was not my own.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: May be ſo; nor is that your own by right, which you hook in by your barbarous advantages; how many raw Cullys have I decoy'd e're now into your ravirous Nooſes.

sp.speaker: Soll.
sp.p: And I think Sir, you us'd to have a conſiderable ſhare.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Did not my Treachery deſerve it?—That I ſhou'd be ſuch a Villain as to ſell my Friends! Well, ſince you have paſt this upon me, I'll do the young Gentleman ſome juſtice upon you.

sp.speaker: Soll.
sp.p: —You can't injure me, the Law will juſtifie me.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Will't juſtifie your contracting with Minors? and taking advantage o their Nonage, by ſome o' your legal Quirks.

sp.speaker: Soll.
sp.p: —There's no ſuch thing, I never exacted ſo.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Have you the Forhead to deny it? Have not I provided you of ſuch Squires as wou'd ſubſcribe to any terms for the relievance o' their preſent wants? I'll unravel all, I'll promiſe you;—We'll plague you, if a Bill in Chancery will do't.

sp.speaker: Soll.
sp.p: —See what that Court will decree for you;—but you are ſo paſſionate, I had rather pay the Money, than be concern'd with you;—So your Servant.

div.stage: Exit. Roman knocks, Shuffle stands cloſe and won't ſpeak. Enters.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: His Door's open, he muſt be within.
Here, here, I want nothing of you; I am none o' your Miſers Ghoſts that haunt you for Treaſure.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I'll promiſe you, I thought, by the authority of your Rap, that you'd been ſome perſon of a worſe deſign; I have been tormented with theſe ſort of Creatures unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Not ſo ill as I have been with another ſort.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Where Prithee?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —In Grays-Inn Walks.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —There's variety of humour;

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —If Apery may be call'd humour.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: It paſſes for it there;—But who did you ſee?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —I ſaw that ſplendid, Orthodox Fop, Jack Rigle, and was troubl'd with him.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Why firſt, after he had run out his Chain o' Thoughts, by way of Greeting, he broke out, Dam-me, he was glad to ſee me, and eſpecially at that Juncture; for he had expreſt his ſenſe o' the Times, Allegorically, in a Letter from Leghorn; and muſt have my judgment on't, which I vouchſaf't very freely, and told him his Stile was tedious and obſcure; he had ſo tag'd it with miſapply'd Figures, that like his Pantaloons, it made a noiſe and was troubleſom.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: And wou'd not he Glout upon't?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: No, but wou'd reconcile me with ſome of his Rhapſodys which he produc't; I read, but he thought I did not give 'em grace enough, and thereupon ſnach't 'em, then thunder'd 'em off in a fancy'd Heroick greatneſs;—but the wofulleſt ſtuff that ever Aqua-fortis writ on Knife, or Tobaco-Box.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He affects that way of tinkling, but with ill ſucceſs commonly.—Well, how was you rid of him?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Another ſeaſonable Fop came ſinging up to us, and took him aſide; then begging my pardon, which I eaſily granted, he turn'd out his Toes, and gracefully mov'd away.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: How did you beſtow your ſelf then?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —I kept my ſeat ſtill, and preſently, two trim, loud Gentlemen ſeated themſelves by me, and made remarks upon all that paſt by; then wou'd bable Gibberiſh to one another, thinking to have it miſtaken for French: Now wou'd be paſſionate and talk of love, making Alluſions to the Trees, and walks; after a while two Ladies came, and took up the Bench below me; which they no ſooner ſaw, but left me and run upon them.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Was not Harry Smirk there?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and ſhoulder'd a tawdry Chamber-Maid along, and bare all the time; he had up all his revis'd motions of head and hand; nor cou'd a female paſs without a diſtorted bow, and an obliging ſmile from him.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He has a pretty impudent familiar way with him;—But was not Madam Burly to be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: O, She's as conſtant as the Uſurer; ſhe was trouling about very painfully, and all mufl'd up in Lace; then, her Knots, her Towers, her Gloves, her Gown, were ſo exact, and ſuiting, they repreſented her a moſt uniform deformity.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You had variety of entertainment indeed.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ay;—there was a poor diſcarded Poet ſitting very penſively under the Covert of an Elm; I pitty'd his ſolitude, and walk't up to him; and after an Epitome of his obſervations, he begun to complain o' the humour o' theſe times; that prefer'd ſilly apiſh Farce, to true ſolid wit.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: May be he had been damn'd lately.—Now let me have your company to the Coffee-houſe; and you ſhall ſee as luxurious a Medly of Manners there, tho' of another nature.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I can't hear a ſordid Slave ſaucily arraign the Proceedings of his Superiours, beſides, Sir Popular and I are at odds.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He won't be at the Cabal this time, he's treating about Marriage with that old harra'ſt Whore, I told you off.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: 'Twill be very merry if ſhe can but bubble him at long run.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Never doubt it; I have whetted him, and am in Fee for my Intereſt o' both ſides; I'll ſerve my ſelf of him, and then expoſe him.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —I muſt go ſteal into his Houſe, which I ſhou'd hate like a Peſt-Houſe, but only that the Divine Juliana's there.

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Popular's Houſe, A Dining-Room.
div.stage: Enter Sir Credulous, and Bravado, as without Wigs and Coats, with 'em Carolietta.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if you had been ſeen in my Chamber, perhaps the occaſion might ha'been cenſur'd too ſeverely; but here's a Cloſet in this Room will ſecure you.

sp.speaker: Brav▪
sp.p: This Whoreſon Boy o' mine! He might ha' been here before this; I ſhall be too late, I have 2 or 3 Cowards to Poſt before 6 a-Clock.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Jeffry ſtays long too;—What an unadvis'd Mortal was I to undertake any thing this particular day; Heſiod reckons it inauſpicious in his Emeralogia; yeſternight the Candle burnt blue, and this Morning I ſaw a Tom-Tit perching upon a Bough with his Tail towards me: I divin'd—

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Hang your Divinations.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Methinks I feel ſome chilling Particles tacitly creeping through my Pores.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Come but into the Cloſet, and I'll fetch either of you a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I fancy this Knight is the moſt humerous Whim that ever made antick Love; I have provided a pleaſanter Maſque than the laſt was, if it have but the good fortune to take—Here are ſome Implements in order to it.

div.stage: Lays down two Vizards on the Table. Exit Carol. Enter at the other ſide Gullman and Faith.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Did'ſt obſerve Wench what a languiſhing kind of a Leer Sir Popular ſquinted at me?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Yes, I believe your Canting Fop is a little carnal; he's juſt ſuch another Arch Wag, as our Brown Betty pickt up in the Rounds one Night.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Ho; I remember him;—He us'd to bring a Sword and Riding coat under his black Cloak, to appear ſparkiſh; he thought his own Habit was too notorious; He was a good friend to the Houſe tho'.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: But he took ſo much Flogging up to't, before one cou'd ſtir his Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Betty wou'd complain, ſhe us'd bodily auſterity upon him, till her Arms ach'd; he was a little dull of Diſcipline, only he paid well.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —A ſhame take her for a Slut, ſhe incroacht upon me that night; he was made prize in my Province;—marry was he.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: He diſpatch'd buſineſs three times a Week in the Blue Chamber conſtantly;—But I hope I ſhall have no need to return to theſe poor ſhifts again.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If the Scriv'ner prove but faithful.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —He's well enough; the pretext of a miſtake will indemnify him; he really has that Widow's Fortunes in his hand that I perſonate;—Then Mr▪ Shuffle will endeavour to promote it for his own ſake.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Now Madam if advice from me wou'd not ſeem a little untimely to one of your experience; I ſhou'd look upon't as the ſafeſt way to ſecure him; to let him command the freedom of your perſon, when you perceive a riſing deſire fermenting in his Veins, he wou'd then certainly Marry you, leaſt the diſcovery of his fall, ſhou'd bring ſcandal to the Fraternity.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: May be Wench he'll take us unawares; therefore leave the Prayer-book upon the Table, and go down.

div.stage: (Faith lays down a Book.) Exit. Enter Sir Popular.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Siſter Spotleſs, I had come ſooner, but that I was obliged to do juſtice upon a wicked Apoſtatizing Brother, nay more, he was taken with a falſe Worſhiper in the very Act of Filthineſs, Foh! Foh! I am ſick with the Repetition.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Oh! abominable, well plainly I am arm'd againſt all the Inſults of lend men, there lies my Sword of Defiance▪

div.stage: Points to her Prayer-Book, which Sir Pop▪ takes up.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: In earneſt a good Woman, I'll warrant it, ſome of our thorough reform'd Authors: Well, the Wicked may talk of their Ability and Learning, but I could as ſoon edifie on the Seven Champions, as the beſt of their Writings; no, no, writing of Divinity to any purpoſe is a ſort of Hereditary Patrimony, which none but our Sanctify'd Brethren can juſtly lay claim to: What! the Title-Page is loſt? What may you call this Siſter?

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: I have e'en forgot the Name, I fall commonly directly to the Matter, 'tis very edifying.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: No doubt on't, a body may know a good Book by Simpathy, my Bowels commonly Simpathize with an Holy Author, before I know one word of his meaning; but let me ſee,
I'll find you out a place preſently that ſuits my Imperfections. Ha! How! What's here? Sure I don't ſee right.

div.stage: (He opens the Book, and it proves to be Obſcene.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Oh! I am ruin'd, 'tis it, but too ſure, that curſed careleſs Jade.

div.stage: Sir Pop. turns into the middle again.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: How! What means this?—Avoid, avoid, O wicked!

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Abominable, Oh Brother ſhe's loſt, ſhe's loſt, utterly loſt, this was that wicked loſt Wretches doing, my ſinful Maid: Oh! Horrid, and defile my Chamber too with it! I muſt e'en take a new Lodging, I ſhall be as fraid to ſtay hereafter, as if the Room was haunted with Spirits.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Turn her away Siſter, ſhe would corrupt a Convert.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: She's a Harlot, an unclean Harlot, and ſhall be no longer under my Roof.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: What will you ſay now if this Pious piece have ſome itching Inclinations this way her ſelf? I can gueſs ſhrewdly by my own Hypocriſie, and believe me, an affected Cant, and a lift or two of the Whites, are the eaſieſt parts of Devotion, I'll attempt her at a diſtance, and if her Inclinations are right, ſhe'll quickly make the moſt of a double meaning Saying.

Well Siſter, I cannot but think of this loſt Creature, but indeed we are all frail; but when we find our ſelves weak, we ſhould apply wholſom Remedies to prevent the growth of our Diſtemper; letus, Dear Siſter, beware of our own ſteps, we know not how ſoon the Minute of Sin may come upon us, we'll arm againſt it; let us be joyn'd together to morrow in Pious Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Ah Brother the memory of my late Husband forbids it, though I muſt confeſs, I wiſh to be ſecure from Temptation as well as may be: But Brother let us burn that filthy obſcene Book, verily I ſhall be ſick whilſt it ſtays in the Room: Oh, I am extream queaſie, t'other day I eat but a little piece of a Pullet that was ſing'd with a Leaf of an old Common-Prayer-Book, and it has lain in my Stomach ever ſince.

div.stage: Sir Popular takes up the Book again and looks in it, and at every Picture be ſhrugs, grinns, and leers at Gullman, who turns up her eyes, and wriggles about Sir Popular.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Well Siſter, we will however ſee the Inventions of the Wicked, and deteſt them: Good lack! Sincerely 'tis pretty to the eye, though it be Leud and Abominable.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Ay, They have the Pleaſures of this vain World.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p:
They have ſo, you little Rogue you; you Pigs-ny's, you little Creature,
ye Pugs-face you.
In earneſt, I am I know not how—As it might be—Strangely, I ſay it Backſliding.—Well, let me be far enough, Is the Canonical hour paſt?
I profeſs, Matrimony ſhall be ratify'd to morrow, you pritty little Fubs you.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Indeed Brother! Oh no, it will be Friday an unluckly day,

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Oh foh! Dear Siſter, that is really Antichriſtian, and Superſtitious; What! An Obſerver of Times and Seaſons? Oh! 'Tis Popery altogether, beſide we muſt not truſt our ſelves too long in the hands of the Tempter: No, no, to Morrow, to Morrow.

div.stage: He takes up the Book again, and looks, and laughs, and ſtroaks Gullman's Bubby's.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Sure you miſtake Brother, it muſt not be by any means.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Why Siſter, why art thou refractory? I tell thee, while our thoughts are upright, we may do what is pleaſing to us: Well, well, my little Spouſe, you are my Spouſe, you Wag you, my Heart is wedded to thee, and I muſt fulfil my juſt deſires with thee; Oh the Comfortable Condition of Wedlock! I ſay Siſter hearken unto me.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: But Brother, the Wicked may ſee us, let us not be a ſtumbling-block before them.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Siſter, here is an Apartment in this Room convenient for us, but leaſt ſome wandring eye ſhould be about the Key-hole, I'll fetch theſe Whirligigs I obſerv'd upon the Table; in earneſt, theſe Vanities may be uſeful though uot lawful.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Well Brother, you are e'en the moſt Powerful Man!

div.stage: They put on the Vizards, and go for the Cloſet, Sir Pop. opens the Door, Sir Cred. and Brav. bolt out and run off, crying Devils, Sir Pop. and Gull. as in confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Siſter, Siſter, make haſte down;—Theſe Royſters have ſet the Houſe in an Uproar;—I'll only ſet things in order, than come to your Lodgings and comfort you.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —I hope if you come 'twill be for an honeſt end Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: How ſtrangly this Creature is infatuated betwixt Luſt and Zeal; This Religion is a pretty ſort of deluding Perſpective, it repreſents all Objects of its own colour;—I have us'd it like a Jac-call, it hunts down the Prey, but never goes to ſhare;—Well, this Surprize had like to have been fatal;—How the Devil came Sir Credulous in this Cloſet, and in that poſture?—A Ourſe upon the Diſappointment: But ſhe'll continue perhaps in her Sacred Rapture;—I'll go to her before her Tranſport be ſettl'd, and renew my Court; This Religious Twang, I perceive, is the moſt prevailing way of Careſs; if I carry her but at laſt, I have play'd the Hypocrite to ſome purpoſe;—'Tis lucre that licenſeth all things, I hate a Conſcience muſt be humour'd.—

lg.l: Mine is a Complaiſant, Good Natur'd Toy,
Demure as City Dames, but never Coy.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange, this dear expected man ſhou'd ſtay, I am all Convulſion till he comes;—My dead, dry'd up Sot is now belching out his noyſome fumes, and weltring upon his Elbows amongſt wet Tobaco on a ſlatter'd Table; whilſt I am preparing for a Luſcious Brimmer of Love, with all the reſtleſs Drought Deſire can cauſe.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: My dear Creature, if this Tranſgreſſion beyond the Period, can be atton'd with the Sacrifice of my Heart; you have kindl'd it with your Eyes, and here I'll offer it.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Indeed I wiſht and fretted till I ſaw you,—But why theſe Flouriſhes? I'll excuſe you without this Eloquence; this is not the Language of Love and Familiarity;—But where were you?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Let me die, if I did not come almoſt directly from Sir Popular's; Madam Charlietta
detain'd me.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: I perceive then I am neglected;—Theſe Men doat on new Miſtreſſes like new Faſhions, tho' the old ones be both more eaſie and graceful.—Well, falſe man, Well.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Prithee my Dear don't pout.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: I am ſure ſhe's as ill ſhap't a Jone as ever was model'd by Rectifier; then her Smile is the oddeſt ſimp'ring air; her Teeth are ruſty in ſpight of all the Operator's art, and fit only to be ſcour'd with a Shooe-Bruſh; then ſhe flouriſheth her Fan ſo awkerdly; and ſhadows with her Patches ſo irregularly; Fough—I admire you can think on her.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Hang her a fond young Slut; ſhe forc't her Maiden-head upon me; and is grown the moſt Inſatiate Creature;—I was forc'd to heap Sin upon Sin, and Lye upon Lye, before I cou'd get, and was excus'd from her; at laſt, with much adoe:—Indeed ſhe preſented me with a Pendulum of a moſt ingenious fancy.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: You baſe, unconſtant Wretch, get you gone, and repleniſh your feeble drain'd Chine with Broths and Jellys, and away to her again.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: My Deareſt! I have plentiful Reſerves ſtill;—Let me ſtifle you with the Sweets of Love.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Well, falſe Man, I'll truſt my Honour in your hands once more, but if you come near her again, may all the Curſes that an injur'd incens'd Rival and a Woman can invent, fall upon you.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: But let us not delay our mutual happineſs, my Dear, all things conſpire to heighten our bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Ay,—the Cuckold ſnores by this time; and the next Room waits us with all its Conveniences;—Here take my hand—

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ha!—What noiſe is this?—Yonder's ſome buſtle below.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, here are a Company of rude Gentlemen that ſwear they'll have this Room,—One of 'em they call Mr. Fluſh—They'r coming up.—

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Oh dear—Alas! I am undone;—He's my Husband's Companion,—Run, run behind the Hangings there, whilſt I go behind the Curtain, that skreens the fire place.

div.stage: They hide themſelves ſeverally. Enter Sir Credulous, Fluſh, Toper, and two Bullies.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Gentlemen, we are now in great Nature's Store-houſe, here's both Wine and Women;—Let every man follow the dictates of his Inclination.—I declare for bowzing; let all ſuch as are Proſelytes for the great Genius o' Goodfellowſhip, hold up their hands.

div.stage: They all hold up but Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: What is the Knight a Heretick?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Marry he deſerves to 'be ſtak't to a Tobaco-pipe, and burnt in Brandy for't.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: His Spurs ſhall be ••… l'd off, his Arms revers't, and his Poſterity attainted.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly Gentlemen, my temperament won't allow it; you ſee I am ſanguine, hot and moiſt; but heat is the predominant quality.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: 'Sbud, is that a Carcaſs to be indulg'd,—Come, come, diſoblige it for compliance and be drunk.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: O Sir, you never think of an Inflammation.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Shaw,—What ſignifies it to be luke-warm a little; I wou'd not ſhirk a Glaſs for a general Conflagration.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Wough, this is a ſtingy humour Sir Credulous;—fill up your thirſty Veins with conſoling Bub, Mun; then fall down dead.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: And when you'r tranſlated to Purgatory, diſgorge your o'recharg'd Stomach, and ſo put out the flame.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A Glaſs or ſo, Gentlemen, is very inſpiring, therefore rather than reta • 'd your Jollity, I'll neglect my ſelf, and take one round.

sp.speaker: All,
sp.p: O rare Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Now for the Quantity and Quality.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Quantity! Fie, fie, no Limitations, Mun;—We are reſolv'd to have a Bout on't, and agreed upon this place as the moſt out o' my Wife's Road;—The Devil's in her if ſhe finds us out here.—What think you?—

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Has ſhe taken my Drops?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ay marry, I ſtole 'em into her Glaſs at Dinner; I ſaw her begin to ſtretch and gape preſently after.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: They'll do her buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Top,
sp.p: —I am as dry as Touch-wood; What ſhall we drink?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —No ſophiſticated French Wine; 'Tis full of Tartar.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —What ſay you to a ſpacious Bowl o' Punch, Genteels.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: —A Bowl o' Punch, a Bowl of Punch.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Hoa—the Houſe—here.—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Go and compound a Bowl o' Punch quickly; you have my Receipt, let it direct you;—only remember to throw in five Quarts of Whitewine to make up a Body.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You ſhall have it Sir.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: How we ſhall duſt it about! Oh—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —My Receit is mightily in requeſt now; They obſerve it altogether at the Tower; I was t'other day amongſt 'em there.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You wou'd find hot ſervice.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Ay, we drunk in Diſcipline, by the Word o' Command;—'Tis the Camp way, and a'mode now.—But how dee like my Panegyrick upon Punch, Sir Credulous?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Moſt raviſhing, I profeſs.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —'Twas a hot-headed Flaſh;—if you did but obſerve, the words are a deſign'd Bombaſt, which is the moſt natural and expreſſive way to deſcribe the lumbring confuſion of a Frolick.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Very adapt indeed,—then the diſparity of your numbers.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Alludes to the diſtraction of the Company;—One Capers, another Cringeth, this tumbles down, another over him, and all are jumbling about in a various Heterocliton of humor.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Yonder comes the Lovely Veſſel—Now ha'for it old Lads.

div.stage: Enter the Servant with a Bowl as at a diſtance.—They ſhout.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Run the proud Argo with all her liquit Fraight aground.

div.stage: He placeth the Bowl upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Now my Souls o' Braſs, let us ſeat our ſelves, and bounce it off; marry if I mind Degree, or Quality, let me never drink more.

div.stage: He ſits down they after him, he takes up the Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Here's a Thimble indeed! Wuh this will never douſe us.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: That! 'Tis like attempting to ſcoup drown'd Zealand clear with an Oyſter-Shell; Let's drink full ones with a Levit of Trumpets at ev'ry Health.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: No, no, That's too extravagant; we'll ſip out o' the Bell of an opening Cowſlip to the buzzing Accents of an Humble Bee.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, Siping! That's very fine;—I am miſtaken if we came hither to Sip;—Go and fetch us a good thumping hollow Beaker, go—Siping Qouth a',—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Prithee, 'tis Porterly to drink Punch out of a Beaker.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Tell not me o' your Genteel Conrtly way of Quaffing, I am for true honeſt, downright drinking.

div.p: There, there, this is the Meaſure.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Let that be the Standard then; I'll ſound it, tho' 'twere as deep as Dooms-day.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly Gentlemen, 'tis too Hyperbolical; but I'll venture to evacuate it once or twice.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: By Styx, I ſcorn to refuſe it.

sp.speaker: 2 Bully.
sp.p: And I, by Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: A Health to our Royal Maſter.

div.stage: The reſt Sing, whilſt he Drinks, And ſo round at every Health.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Hah my brave Boys! Is not this better than Plotting, and Leaguing, and Clanning and Shamming? A Pox o' theſe unquiet Curs, that muſt be yelping againſt Heavens Luminary, and only becauſe 'tis bright.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A troubleſom Crowd of Inſects, that are Peſtilential to the heat that preſerves 'em.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: That Buz like Bottl'd-Ale, and only make a noiſe becauſe they'r froathy;—Foh—the very naming 'em furrs my Mouth;—I muſt e'en rence it with a Bumper or two.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: —Ah rare Toper! Thou art the Prince of a Man.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Y' Good Faith you Rogues, you ſee the worſt o' me; I only Plot how to avoid the Slavery my Wife wou'd Plunge me in, and to enjoy my Liberty in a Chimney Corner, with a Pot and a Pipe before me.

sp.speaker: 2 Bully.
sp.p: —By Lucifer that's reaſonable enough.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I tell you truth, or let this be my laſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You have none o' this at the Univerſity, Mr. Fluſh.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Drinking is look't upon as a perfection there; if a young Blade after four years Reſidence, has but learn'd to make a Supernaculum; and as much Logick as will prove a Country-man to he a Horſe, he's a good Proficient.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Indeed!—Sleepy Jack Seaton, or honeſt old Hereboord's will teach 'um the latter preſently.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Let's about with it, and be ſprightly my Men o'Mirth, ten Goe-down's to you Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred:
sp.p: Generous Mr. Fluſh I am yours to Intoxication.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: Dear Sir, your Devoted.

sp.speaker: 2 Bully.
sp.p: Dear Tom, I am thine.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Don't limit me, Mun, I am heavy, and muſt fall to the bottom, marry muſt I.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Gallant Toper, thou ſhalt be Canoniz'd y' faith.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —A Saint Man!

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ay, and of as good Authority as any in the Calender's—Shrove. Tueſday ſhall be your Anniverſary.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: By Stix, his Face is like a Holiday already.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Nay, but if you'll honour me, make me the Prince of Drunkards.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: We will;—and your Inauguration ſhall be to morrow; 'Tis too late now for the Solemnity.

sp.speaker: 2 Bully.
sp.p: We'll all be his Peers.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ay, his Mightineſs ſhall confer Dignities upon us all; 'tis uſual now adays for a private Club to frame a new Conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: And why may not we, as well as the ſober Party;—but how far man ſhall my Dominions extend?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Throughout all the Taverns, Brandy-Shops, and Ale-houſes, betwixt White-Chappel and St. Giles's.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ah—I ſhall be a happy Prince—Duke Trinkelo ſhall be my Allie.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Myriads of Mirmidons ſhall defend your Reeling Mightineſs from Conſtable and Watch, Pillars and Poſts, from Chamber-pots above, and Channels below, and all ſuch Hoſtilities.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ha ha, What, no Laws?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Yes, yes, but Lex bibendi, ſhall be Lex ſuprema, the reſt ſhall be digeſted into a Code.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Marry, I ſhall be a Prince preſently at this rate, I am as Drunk as a Lord a'ready.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: The other Stoup old Toaſt.
Ho, hoa,—'Tis down by Stingo.

sp.speaker: Top:
sp.p: Ay, if 'twill but ſtay,
This Punch is plaguy cucutting Liquor.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ha ha ha—run behind the Curtain there, into the Fire-place, and disburthen.

div.stage: He reels thither, draws by the Curtain, runs back, Amaz. after him, he falls, ſhe over him, the Company riſe.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Udsbodikins; how came this Incarnate Devil here;

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: O thou lumpiſh, weltring Swine, thou ſtupid Log,—Here's a pickle with all my heart—Sirrah, Beaſt, how came you amongſt theſe roaring Rake-hells, theſe tearing debaucht Ruffians?—I cou'd find to pull thoſe big, rouling eyes out, that ſtare and glow in your Fool's Noddle—I thought I ſhou'd find out your Haunts at laſt.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: I believe Madam we have rather found out yours, how cou'd you ſlink in hither unſeen? I gueſs you expected ſome-body, you wou'd ha' been civiler too.—
sp.stage: (She runs at him, he goes back.)
sp.p: Touch me, and I'll ha' you ſtript, and turn'd down Stairs;—Don't preſume the Privilege o' your Sex ſhall excuſe you.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Thou pitiful, profligate Shirk;—He that gives thee but a Pot o' Brandy's thy Darling; ay, for one poor Pipe o' Smoak, Thou'lt call a dull drouſie Pluraliſt, a diligent ſound man; a poor poatching Pettyfogger, an able Council; a Penny Pamphleteer, an Authentick Author; or a Tooth-pick-maker a Virtuoſo; thou off-ſcouring o' the Town, how durſt thou pronounce ſo impudently upon me? Sirrah, I'll make you know there's never a Houſe of Entertainment, within the Sound o' Bow bell, which I ha • e not a Spie in—I'll—

div.stage: (Flies at him, and pulls of his Wig.) Fluſh knocks, enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —A Cord here quickly—
Now Gentlemen, if we think to continue Company, we muſt reſolve to tie her down to a Chair, and Gag her—Here's a Gag—

sp.speaker: Bullys.
sp.p: Agreed.

div.stage: They Gag her and tie her down.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Tie me! Brutes,—Raſcals.—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: But are you ſure ſhe's faſt?—Come—lets e'en take of our Liquor peaceably and lovingly,—A Po-Pox take her for a—

div.stage: He gets to the Table and drinks alone.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ay, Gape on till your Jaws crack.
Sirrah, how came this Fury here.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I know not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Get you gone you Pimping Rogue, and let her down into the next Room through the Trap-door, that Deviſe to eſcape Conſtable;—if you untie her Sirrah, I'll confound you worſe than the Pox has done.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Sure there has been ſome default, elſe my Guttae Soporiferae had charm'd her as faſt as an Incantation.

div.stage: The Door opens, ſhe ſinks and makes a noiſe, they laugh.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, ſince the Bawd o' the houſe has inform'd o' the Company, let us batter the Windows, flaſh the Hangings, break the Chairs, and fight our ſelves out in the Uproar.

sp.speaker: 1 Buly.
sp.p: We'll rout 'em by Jove.

sp.speaker: 2 Bully.
sp.p: Hey for a ſcouring Frolick.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Now for the Onſet;—Come my Squires, follow your Knight,

div.stage: (They go to the place where Bravado abſconds.)

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Here let's demoliſh all before us, and rip the Hangings up in order.

div.stage: He goes to thruſt in his Sword, Bravado breaks out.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: I proteſt I'll make one with you my honeſt old rending Rogues;—let's pull down the houſe, and cruſh the Sinful Crew.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Bravado! So ſo—the Miſtery's explain'd now; Toper, I give you Joy o' your ſtately branching head.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Wuh, What's the matter man?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Oh nothing, nothing;—You are only Cuckolded, and by this ſame honeſt Gentleman here.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Marry, but I'm miſtaken if he eſcape ſo;—make him drink half a dozen Bumpers for his pains.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ha ha, Seriouſly Mr. Toper bears it with the indifference of a Stoick.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are well diſpos'd; but let me die, I don't underſtand you;—I had an Aſſignation here, with a Perſon of Quality, and expected her ev'ry Minute; a Devil on your unſeaſonable Invaſion, 'Tis at leaſt a hundred Broads out o' my way.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: But why did you abſcond, we are all known to you?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —You came poud'ring up Stairs with ſuch Authority, I was afraid you had been a Legion of Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: But why did you not appear upon acquaintance with our Voices?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Why' Pox I thought you wou'd oblige me to Drink, and my Palate is ſo Debauch't, ſince my laſt Randezvous with my Lord, that any liquid thing's a Potion to me.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: All theſe Wheadles won't take;—But to ſhow you how tender I am of theſe Amorous Miſcarriages, I'll prevail upon the Cuckold and Company to leave you to the Complement of your Intrigue.—Come, Gentlemen, let's Troop.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Wuh, the Bo-bowl is not out yet Man.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Do but you get rowl'd down Stairs, and you ſhall have as much as you can ſwill.—Come, 'tis late.

div.stage: Exeunt, leading Toper, two Bullys Singing.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Now muſt I go and enlarge my unfortunate Herion that ſuffers in Limbo; then our twiſted Souls ſhall reliſh all the boundleſs Joys, that Paſſion endear'd by Diſappointment can contribute.

lg.l: The Drunkard is the kind contented Aſs,
He ne'er Reſents, but when you take his Glaſs.

div.head: SCENE I. A Bed Chamber.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: WHat a ſhame's the matter with me trow?—I am as Sick as a Horſe, and I'm ſure I had not above ſix Quarts 'i my Guts—Foh—here's the ſtrangeſt taſte 'i my Mouth methinks (Spits) marry I think my throat 's clogg'd quite up with Rubbiſh—oa—'tis as rough as bad waies in froſty Weather;—How my Pulſes heave, and my Arms ſhake and dindle 'i. Oh! How a good draught of ſmall Beer wou'd hiſs down! (He ſtretches) But 'tis near morning ſure—they are not up 'i the Houſe—I never was thus out 'i tune before; I have catch'd cold under the Table whilſt I ſlept, altho they had laid three or four Chairs upon me;—and theſe one wou'd ha' thought might ha' kept me warm.—Is there never a Couch in this Room think ye, nor a Fire-place ſtrow'd with Ruſhes (he gropes about) What's this—a Bed—Ah!—this is comfortable—I ſhall be a happy Man if Fluſh find me not out and unkennel me:—Marry, I'll 'een take a comfortable Nap; then riſe up Freſh, and ſlay 'em ev'ry Soul.

div.stage: (He lies down.) Enter Servant, with a Candle after him, Bravado and Amazonia.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Are you ſure Sweet-heart we may be ſecure here.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: —Ay Madam;—He, they call Toper, is lying dead Drunk under the Parlor Table, I have newly bolted him in; the reſt tumble together in the ſame condition above in the Garret.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Here—be you Centinel below?

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: —But did you tell the Company that ſome Body had releas'd me; and that I was gone, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Ay, and they believed it.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: But did not they ſuſpect us, think you?

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —No, no,—I made ev'ry thing clear.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: —Now let me tell you ſuch a Tranſaction, as will heighten our Appetites to the delicious Banquet.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: —Mine, my lovely Angel is ſo eager already, that Artifice can't improve it;—I am all Heat and Youth; my Eyes tremble, my Breaſt pants and throws; my Nerves frisk, my Breath quivers, and a kindly generous Fire thrills in my Veins.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: —Whilſt I am ready to receive your kindeſt Tenders with an equal warmth.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Let's haſten therefore, to let looſe our bounding Paſſions to their abſolute Range and Forrage.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: I am all Complyance.

div.stage: (Brav. lays his Sword and Hat upon the Table, makes the Door fast, takes her hand.)

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Now my Angel, let me lead thee to the Stage of love, to act the ſofteſt part that e'er was utter'd in broken ſighs.

div.stage: He leads her to the Bed ſide, ſhe withdraws the Curtain, ſpies Toper.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Ha! my Husband!—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —Piſh Man—the Cup does not ſtand at me—What—are you here Sweet-heart?

div.stage: Amaz. ſigns to Brav. to go out.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Thou Eternal Sot!—I'll ſmother-thee in the Bed-Cloaths▪

div.stage: She muffles his Head and holds him down, Brav. opens the door and is running out, but is ſtopt by Fluſh and two Bullies.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Are you here!—Come, you ſhall back with us.

sp.speaker: Brav.
sp.p: Good honeſt dear Rogue excuſe me; I am ſleepy, I muſt to Bed.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: What, you are afraid to diſoblige your Complexion: Come prithee, we want a fourth man till Toper be caſt up.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Heavens!—I am diſcover'd—What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: —Ay!—The Lady Amazonia!—Your Servant Madam, you will find out your Husbands Haunts, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: My Husband! I ſcorn it, I diſown him; my Vow, in the Church was extorted from me, and therefore it can't oblige; I always hated him, and had rather throw my ſelf into the Embraces of a Leper, cruſted all over with an uncurable Scurf, than into his feeble Paralitick Arms.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Marry Sweet-heart, an you befor that, I am as indifferent as your ſelf; I had rather lay my Lips to the Bung-hole of a Beer-Barrel, than Salute the fineſt o' your Sex, and there's for you again.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: No wonder ſhe oppos'd your keeping Company with this rigour; it ſeems, that too great plenty of Liquor, by a common kind of an Antiperiſtaſis has dry'd you;—You are no farther uſeful then only to ſupply her with Money and Opportunities; this is the Spark that relieves her with all other ſatisfactions.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: O Sir, much good may doe you; you are happy, you have done more than ever I cou'd do;—I cou'd never pleaſe her, by my Faith.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Thou! no truly I think not; I never lov'd to have you come yawning in my face, and infeſting me with your undecocted Lees of Ale, a Hogo ſtrong enough to fetch one out of a Fit o' the Epilepſie;—out upon't—A Dray-horſe were as good a Bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Since your Ladyſhip's ſo very nice and delicate, I wou'd adviſe you to avoid theſe groſs Hogo's, and devote your ſelf altogether to this rare, calcin'd Peice.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: O happy Opportunity! Gentlemen, you are Witneſſes of her Infamy; Now let's go and drink a dozen and conſult over it about a Divorce.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.p: Ay, do, do, the Law will force you to allow me Alimony, but if it ſhou'd not; I have provided againſt all Extremities, and will never ſee you more;—ſo a fig for you—Adieu Cuckold—Come, my Dear.—

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: —Prodigious Impudence!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Now my Ranting Rogues, let's go and Carous for Joy; now I may tipple undiſturb'd, and be accountable to no body, ye Raſcals;—I'll never ſleep without a Roundlet o' Brandy under my head, and when I die let overflowing Cups drop tears o' my Tomb—Hah Boys—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Whilſt my finger draws out a liquid Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —I ſhall love thee my old Trojan whilſt I live, for trapaning my fierce Mrs. Damnable thus;—I ſhall faith. Fluſh We were forc't to corrupt the Scout.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —But heark you mun—Who is this ſame young Fellow that Sparks her thus?

sp.speaker: Fluſh▪
sp.p: The moſt White-liver'd Coward that ever took advantage; and a modiſh ſort of a Fop that is proud to be reckon'd a Debauchee;—He'll boaſt of his Venereal Misfortunes, as ſo many Badges of Immortal Honour; and is as proud of a Surgeon's Bill, as a Noble-man's Chaplain is of his Scarf;—There's not a Great Perſon about Court, but is his Familiar, he pretends; Nor a taking Nameleſs Pamphlet, which he does not adopt;—He's a—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: So mun ſo, we have had enough of him here, let's diſcourſe the reſt of his Qualities over a Glaſs;—we'll go to Harry's, he's an honeſt Fellow, he'll broach a freſh run for us.—Come, my Three Merry Boys, I ſhall be a Prince indeed now.—Hey Boys.—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ay, and as abſolute as your Draught; you ſhall be no more Homager to your quondam Imperial Confort; we all ſwear Fealty to your Diadem; and Brimmers ſhall be tender'd as the Teſt;—he that knocks under board ſhall be look't upon as a Diſſenter, and amerc't a Penal Groat the next Morning.—Come.—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: No wonder, Madam, your ſo ſoon this Morning, ſince this is almoſt the laſt hour you can call your ſelf your own; ſure your Barbarous Uncle will revoke the too ſevere Doom.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No,—he'll urge it with all the rigour that lucre can provoke him to;—he knows my averſion forfeits half my Portion; but rather than contract a holy Vow with any other than your dear ſelf, I'll reſign my life too, as a burthen without ye.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Alas, my wondrous Creature, I am each way unworthy of ſo divine a Bleſſing; my Fortunes are as mean as my Deſerts;—I have ne'er a gaudy Coach grac't with a Rank of Lacquies to attend you; no ſupple French Valet calls me Maſter; I have no ſwelling Titles, no fawning Paraſites, no—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But Nature has enrich't you with Treaſures more valuable, and tho' the Remains of my divided Portion won't be an equivalent to your Merits, I am ſure my Paſſion will.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
How cou'd I ſee the lovelieſt thing my heart e'er knew, in a ſtation beneath her too great Worth and Beauty! No, my ſole delight, rather than throw
away your Excellencies upon one wou'd undo you, ſurrender your ſelf up to your Uncles Pleaſure, and Marry the Party he deſigns▪ he's rich, and can ſupport you in an Equipage ſultable to your Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And can you be ſo unkind as to leave me now after all your large Profeſſions? Pray don't;—I can't ſuffer whilſt you are neer me; we'll injoy more Wealth in one another's Love, than all the World can give; and when my ſlender Competency fails, I can Limn, Embroyder, work Lace, and do a thouſand ſuch pretty trifling Knacks.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Thou Mirrour of Perfections! Thy goodneſs has amaz'd me;—When Love goes to draw Seraphick Sweetneſs with a Cherub's Face, Thou ſhalt ſit to the little Genius.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Then ſince you think I deſerve you, Why de'e grudge me the Preſent of your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Madam, I am no more my own; tho' I fear the gift may be fatal; if the viſible Univerſe were mine to give you, I ſhou'd think it too mean a Joynture.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Indeed Couſin, the Knight will be here preſently; 'tis time now to ſettle your looks into a Marriage Figure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Is Sir Popular reſolv'd upon't ſtill?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Ay, ay,—he's unalterable in ſuch a caſe as this; he expects you'll rather be nick't o' your 5000 l. than conſent to the Match.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Some o' theſe Aldermen have Conſciences as large as their Charter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have not ſeen this Sir Credulous above thrice; the laſt time was yeſterday, and then I us'd him ſo, I thought he wou'd ha' made no more Advances.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Truly he reſented your Carriage, after his way; I found him in a moderate Foam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And did not you tell me he reſolv'd I ſhou'd die for him, rather than he wou'd prevent it with one kind word?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —I did ſo, and more then that, he was ſo ſweet upon me I was half afraid he wou'd ha' Ladyfi'd me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Why ſuch a change then?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Sir Popular was with him before five this Morning, and tamper'd with his Fool-ſhip then, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: They'r both very quick.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ay, Matrimony now a-days, requires as little warning as in the Playhouſe; where the Parties ſhall make the firſt Interview in the Fourth Act, and Marry in the Fifth.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ladies, your humble Servant: this, I underſtand is like to be a jovial day.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Popular intends to have a band o' Fiddles towards the Evening.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: No, no, he's for none o' your Cat-gut Minſtrelſie; but prithee Roman, What pretences can you have here now?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Why truly Shuffle as many as ever I had.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Well, but this is no time for fooling;—in ſhort, the buſineſs is this—

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Marries this very day, and is now at Sir Credulous Trinket's.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He ſtays to bring Sir Credulous along with him, in order to Marry Madam Juliana at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But he ſhall find he can't diſpoſe of me.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: But he can diſpoſe of part o' your Portion then, and that conſideration will ſatisfie him as well.—Pray Madam, let me underſtand your Circumſtances in this caſe, 'tis poſſible I may releive you.

sp.speaker: 1 Bully.
sp.p: —Prodigious Impudence!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Now my Ranting Rogues, let's go and Carous for Joy; now I may tipple undiſturb'd, and be accountable to no body, ye Raſcals;—I'll never ſleep without a Roundlet o' Brandy under my head, and when I die let overflowing Cups drop tears o' my Tomb—Hah Boys—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Whilſt my finger draws out a liquid Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —I ſhall love thee my old Trojan whilſt I live, for trapaning my fierce Mrs. Damnable thus;—I ſhall faith▪

sp.speaker: Fluſh
sp.p: We were forc't to corrupt the Scout.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: —But heark you mun—Who is this ſame young Fellow that Sparks her thus?

sp.speaker: Fluſh▪
sp.p: The moſt White-liver'd Coward that ever took advantage; and a modiſh ſort of a Fop that is proud to be reckon'd a Debauchee;—He'll boaſt of his Venereal Misfortunes, as ſo many Badges of Immortal Honour; and is as proud of a Surgeon's Bill, as a Noble-man's Chaplain is of his Scarf;—There's not a Great Perſon about Court, but is his Familiar, he pretends; Nor a taking Nameleſs Pamphlet, which he does not adopt;—He's a—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: So mun ſo, we have had enough of him here, let's diſcourſe the reſt of his Qualities over a Glaſs;—we'll go to Harry's, he's an honeſt Fellow, he'll broach a freſh run for us.—Come, my Three Merry Boys, I ſhall be a Prince indeed now.—Hey Boys.—

sp.speaker: Fluſh.
sp.p: Ay, and as abſolute as your Draught; you ſhall be no more Homager to your quondam Imperial Conſort; we all ſwear Fealty to your Diadem; and Brimmers ſhall be tender'd as the Teſt;—he that knocks under board ſhall be look't upon as a Diſſenter, and amerc't a Penal Groat the next Morning.—Come.—

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Popular's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: No wonder, Madam, your ſo ſoon this Morning, ſince this is almoſt the laſt hour you can call your ſelf your own; ſure your Barbarous Uncle will revoke the too ſevere Doom.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No,—he'll urge it with all the rigour that lucre can provoke him to;—he knows my averſion forfeits half my Portion; but rather than contract a holy Vow with any other than your dear ſelf, I'll reſign my life too, as a burthen without ye.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Alas, my wondrous Creature, I am each way unworthy of ſo divine a Bleſſing; my Fortunes are as mean as my Deſerts;—I have ne'er a gaudy Coach grac't with a Rank of Lacquies to attend you; no ſupple French Valet calls me Maſter; I have no ſwelling Titles, no fawning Paraſites, no—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But Nature has enrich't you with Treaſures more valuable, and tho' the Remains of my divided Portion won't be an equivalent to your Merits, I am ſure my Paſſion will.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p:
How cou'd I ſee the lovelieſt thing my heart e'er knew, in a ſtation beneath her too great Worth and Beauty! No, my ſole delight, rather than throw
away your Excellencies upon one wou'd undo you, ſurrender your ſelf up to your Uncles Pleaſure, and Marry the Party he deſigns; he's rich, and can ſupport you in an Equipage ſuitable to your Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And can you be ſo unkind as to leave me now after all your large Profeſſions? Pray don't;—I can't ſuffer whilſt you are neer me; we'll injoy more Wealth in one another's Love, than all the World can give; and when my ſlender Competency fails, I can Limn, Embroyder, work Lace, and do a thouſand ſuch pretty trifling Knacks.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Thou Mirrour of Perfections! Thy goodneſs has amaz'd me;—When Love goes to draw Seraphick Sweetneſs with a Cherub's Face, Thou ſhalt ſit to the little Genius.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Then ſince you think I deſerve you, Why de'e grudge me the Preſent of your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Madam, I am no more my own; tho' I fear the gift may be fatal; if the viſible Univerſe were mine to give you, I ſhou'd think it too mean a Joynture.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Indeed Couſin, the Knight will be here preſently; 'tis time now to ſettle your looks into a Marriage Figure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Is Sir Popular reſolv'd upon't ſtill?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Ay, ay,—he's unalterable in ſuch a caſe as this; he expects you'll rather be nick't o' your 5000 l. than conſent to the Match.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Some o' theſe Aldermen have Conſciences as large as their Charter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have not ſeen this Sir Credulous above thrice; the laſt time was yeſterday, and then I us'd him ſo, I thought he wou'd ha' made no more Advances.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Truly he reſented your Carriage, after his way; I found him in a moderate Foam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And did not you tell me he reſolv'd I ſhou'd die for him, rather than he wou'd prevent it with one kind word?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —I did ſo, and more then that, he was ſo ſweet upon me I was half afraid he wou'd ha' Ladyfi'd me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Why ſuch a change then?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Sir Popular was with him before five this Morning, and tamper'd with his Fool-ſhip then, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: They'r both very quick.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ay, Matrimony now a-days, requires as little warning as in the Playhouſe; where the Parties ſhall make the firſt Interview in the Fourth Act, and Marry in the Fifth.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ladies, your humble Servant: this, I underſtand is like to be a jovial day.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Popular intends to have a band o' Fiddles towards the Evening.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: No, no, he's for none o' your Cat-gut Minſtrelſie; but prithee Roman, What pretences can you have here now?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Why truly Shuffle as many as ever I had.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Well, but this is no time for fooling;—in ſhort, the buſineſs is this—

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Marries this very day, and is now at Sir Credulous Trinket's.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He ſtays to bring Sir Credulous along with him, in order to Marry Madam Juliana at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But he ſhall find he can't diſpoſe of me.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: But he can diſpoſe of part o' your Portion then, and that conſideration will ſatisfie him as well.—Pray Madam, let me underſtand your Circumſtances in this caſe, 'tis poſſible I may releive you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Thus Sir;—5000 l. was left me by an Uncle his Elder Brother, upon condition I ſhou'd conſent to Marry the firſt Match that Sir Popular offer'd me; otherwiſe, the Legacy was to fall to him, provided it cou'd appear, that he had only propounded my Fortune, and no indirect means to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: 'Tis exactly as I repreſented it to you yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Ay, and obſerve what uſe I have made on't already;—you muſt know, he has ſham'd Sir Credulous out of a 1000 l. this Morning; and by my procurement, has quitted all his future Claims to Madam Juliana's Legacy by a General Releaſe, which is now in Sir Credulous's Cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —Well,—but Sir Credulous will re-deliver it, I ſuppoſe, upon the breach o' the Match.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —You ſhall hear—I have perſwaded him to preſent it to the Lady, after her conſent; as a means to work upon her Ingenuity, by making her Miſtreſs of her own Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: So ſhe muſt ſeem to give her aſſent.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, be ſure you ſweeten him up as if you were his own; I'll contrive to Spirit him out o' the way, till Sir Popular be Marry'd, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: There will be no need on't; ſhe may abſent her ſelf, after 'tis in her Poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: But de'e ſee;—I am intereſted in Sir Popular's Marriage, and muſt endeavour to maintain a plauſible underſtanding betwixt Sir Credulous and him, till the Ceremony in the Church be conſummated;—in ſhort, I have ſome Money due from Sir Popular for a ſecret ſervice.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: I partly apprehend you;—ſo that, you wou'd ſecure Sir Credulous, till you had receiv'd your Sum, leaſt his diſturbance might be of ill conſequence to you.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay, ay,—Now, Sir Popular having a 1000 l. by him, he'll diſcharge me without any farther trouble, rather than have me expoſe him.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Beſides,—his contracting with Sir Credulous upon ſuch an account, tho' indirectly, will invalidate his Title, by the Condition of the Will.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: But prithee don't you be ſeen here, till you receive a Summons from me;—I'll to the Bridge, and order her to detain Sir Popular, till the other Knight be diſpos'd off.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: This Mr. Shuffle is ſuch another; he'll over-reach my Uncle if it be poſſible to do't.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, there's a hopeful proſpect of circumventing him now; but it will be convenient for the better circulation of the buſineſs, that I abſent my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: My heart, you'll remember the faith that is betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: How unſeaſonably you remind me;—Can the Tenant forget the Service he holds all his Lands by? Or a Beggar the needy moving Cant that ſuſtains him? But you cou'd not doubt me ſure; your Idea Sollicits for you, and never leaves me; it diſtracts my thoughts, and breaks my ſlumbers; I muſt rove about like a reſtleſs Ghoſt till I ſee you again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —And when muſt I expect you, my Thoughts?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —About an hour hence I hope;—till then the whole Hierarchy protect you.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I fancy Couſin this love is a pretty pleaſant Bable; there's ſuch dying Leers, ſuch unaccountable Geſtures, ſuch ſoft confuſion amongſt you.—Methinks I cou'd wiſh for a little experience of that antick Foolery, only for an opportunity to laugh at my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Cou'd not Mr. Bravado bring you acquainted with it?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: No,—He has a Quarrel againſt me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Some Love Skirmiſh.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —He Swears, he'll never ſee me again, which Oath I hope he'll obſerve.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Does he ſuſpect the Humour you paſt upon him Yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I almoſt fancy ſo;—ſome had been fooling with the Viſards, and ſo Bug-bear'd both of 'em out o' the Cloſet, elſe I had trick't 'em neatly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But you muſt leave theſe Merriments now;—our new Aunt's ſeverity won't diſpence with 'em.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —We ſhall be worſe peſter'd now with a Religious Din, than ever; there'll be ſuch ſcrewing o' Faces, and drawing o' Sentences through the Noſe, amongſt the Aſſembly.—Well, if ſhe don't prove a right one in the concluſion, I am miſtaken.

div.stage: Enter Sir Popular, and Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Kinſ-woman, I have brought you the Gentleman I deſign for your Husband, and I conceive he may be a proportionable Match for you;—Therefore prepare for Marriage this very day.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —The notice is very ſhort, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Let this be the day Lady by all means; the Aſteriſms are in a very amicable aſpect, and ſeem to be our Genial Torches;—if we ſhou'd decline this Invitation, perhaps their future poſition might continue malevolent out o' revenge.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Kinſwoman, I charge you be advis'd by me, and be joyn'd forthwith; He's a good man, and has a comfortable Fortune, I conceive.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sir, I never knew how to diſobey you.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: In earneſt, very meekly anſwer'd;—Well, I have ſome Negotiations to look after; after I have attended theſe, we'll all go together, and diſpatch the pious Affair.—Hem—

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Then Sir, you have forgot your Aſſeverations to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Seriouſly, Sweet Madam, I was aſſail'd with ſuch violence, in this fair Ladies behalf, by my worthy Friend Sir Popular that I am not impowr'd to diſoblige him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So rather then be uncivil to him, you'll do injuſtice to her;——O good Sir, let not me in the leaſt be the cauſe of ſuch an Immortality!

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Fie Couſin;—here's a coldneſs indeed, and ſuch approaching Joys in proſpect!—Believe me, there's no other engagement betwixt us, than the obligation of common Civility.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Indeed, Fair Lady, I muſt confeſs, your Couſin was not thought unworthy of thoſe reſpectful Tenders you neglected yeſterday; but upon ſecond thoughts, I did believe your ill-advis'd Behaviour to be the effects of your Modeſty, and do therefore remit your miſcarriage.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Twere pity Sir, to treſpaſs on ſo good a Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly, moſt excellent Being, Choler never predominates with me, I can allow for Sublunary Failures.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Or elſe you'd Maſſacr'd Bravado yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: He's an abuſive Gentleman, and did impoſe a little too much upon my Mediocrity.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Have you ſeen him ſince, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly, fine Lady, no;—I was Arreſted by a Gang of good Fellows; they wou'd have me make one with 'em;—'Twas paſt Ten of the Clock when I left 'em, I cou'd not endure it any longer; there was ſuch Drinking, and ſtorming, and ſcuffling;—Here lay a Hat, there a Wig, here one lay ſupine, there another;—I profeſs you might ha' ſeen as various a Horchpotch as in a Giblet Pye.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But don't you find your ſelf indiſpos'd this Morning, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: The Emulſion has cool'd me a little, but I am cloudy ſtill; elſe I had invented ſome uncommon curioſity, for the Illuſtration of our Nuptial Solemnity.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Some Mask, or Fire-works?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: No, no, theſe are dull—A pair of Turtles ſupporting a Pageant that repreſents the Solitary Phoenix, firſt warbling out an Epithalamium, and then expiring in a Spicy Flame, wou'd be a high Conceit.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: You have Travel'd, Sir, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: O very far, and altogether in ſearch of Nature, which I found at laſt in ſpight of all her Mazes, and am now improving her into an Art.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Queſtionleſs;—I am now teaching a Magpy to diſcourſe in form, a Snail to walk erect, a Sammon to become Amphibious, and graze in Medows;—In ſhort, I am teaching Nature to be unnatural.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: And has wrought the Experiment upon himſelf.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —You'll out-doe the Greſhamites.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: O, they are a Phegmatick Society.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: —Sure your Education has been coſtly, Sir Credulous?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Coſtly!—Ay, I think it has:—So much at Amſterdam for learning to eat a Lobſter; ſo much at Paris for mounting a Kite, ſo much at Madrid for ſcourging a Top—

sp.speaker: Jul.
