sp.p: —Your own Country might have accompliſht you with theſe Perfections.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: O you are much miſtaken, fair Madam;—your Forreigners are more polite a great deal; there's not a Curioſity Maſter in England, let me tell you ſo much.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Why, Sir, is the breaking up of a Lobſter a Curioſity?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: A choice one believe me—But now for my more ſolid and ſubſtantial Sciences;—There's firſt—

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: May I give you Joy, Sir Credulous?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: You may antidate your Salutation, if you pleaſe.

div.stage: Shuffle takes a part with Carol.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: —Now there's ſome appearance of a Delivery from him, and all his Odious Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: We'll leave you with this Gentleman, Sir;—your Brides Dreſs muſt be refin'd a little.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Have you preſented your Lady with Sir Popular's diſcharge yet?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly I had forgot.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —O fie,—run after her with it—quick—

div.stage: Sir Credulous runs out, and Re-enters.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —I forc't it into her hand;—ſhe expects 'tis ſome Song, I'll warrant you;—She loves me extreamly, I knew the vertueo' the Philter was irreſiſtible.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Udds me! Now you talk of Philters;—Who de'e think did me the honour to take notice o' me this Morning?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Who, pray?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —The fam'd Aſtrologer, Rabbie Nathan, born a Jew, but bred a Chaldean for ſome time;—you muſt be acquainted with his Fame certainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: O Sir, who can be a Stranger to't? Wou'd our Perſonal Acquaintance were as great.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: He's at preſent hard by; I'll ſend the Foot-boy to him to deſire his Company here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred
sp.p: We ſhou'd ha' ſent in more formality to ſuch a Perſonage as he is.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —He's a moſt obliging Man in his way;—I am confident he'll come, if he be not gone to the Synagogue;—it ſeems there is ſome Jewiſh Rite perform'd there to day.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Has he any English?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Yes, but almoſt as broken as his Nation.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —I have tome little ſmattering of Hebrew, but none of Chaldy.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: No! why the Radix is altogether the ſame; Chaldy was only the more Courtly Dialect.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —But is his Engliſh intelligible?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Yes, only a little harſh and broad.—He's here—

div.stage: Enter the Quack in a Fur Cap, and ſhag'd Gown.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Hail Rabbie Shoffle.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: All Hail moſt Honourable Prophet.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: —I am hoonly a Magus haan dee Divine by Cauſes naatouraal.

div.stage: He looks earneſtly upon Sir Cred.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Mr. Rabby, I ſhall think my ſelf highly honour'd, if your Reverence will condeſcend to Dine with me.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Nay, I neever eat with the hun-circumcis'd; I ſmell no Chriſtian Pork.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —If this Rogue don't forget his Leſſon, we ſhall have ſucceſs.

div.stage: Quack looks in Sir Credulous's hand.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: I Swere, thou haaſt ha mole hin the hollow of thy haam.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Seriouſly I have ſo; is it his skill in Palmiſtry that directs him, think we?

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Thou doſt purpoſe to take to thy ſelf a Wife before the ſixth hour.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I profeſs, a moſt Incomparable Man.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Nay, nay,—The Plaanets, aan the Fowls of the Aar, aan the Flaame, aan the Smook, aan the Entrails, aan the Shears, aan the Ompha do forbid thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ay!—Then my Calculation was not exact.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Rabbie's Infallible;—there has been ſome miſtake in your Scheme.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Louk een this Glaſs, aan thou ſhaalt behold the Revolution of thy days; It waas the South-ſayer Uzzi's, whou waas ouf the Tribe ouf Lettle Benjamin.

div.stage: He gives Sir Cred. a Perſpective, Sir Cred. looks in't, Shuf. ſigns the Quack to Sir Cred's Pockets, Quack feels the out-ſide, and ſhakes his Head.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I profeſs Rabby, I can ſcarce diſcern any thing.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: —That ees becauſe thou waants my Veſtments; cloath thy ſaalf een them, aan thy Fortune ſhaall appear; they were Conſecrated when I ſojourn'd in the Saandy Deſart, aand have a Proognoſticating Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I beſeech you moſt Reverend Rabbie, let me try 'em.—A Profound Man!

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: puts off his Coat and Breeches gives'em to Quack, puts on his Breeches and Gown.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Come, Sir Credulous I'll help you to hold it ſteddy.

div.stage: He lays his Arm about Sir Cred's Neck, Quack rifles his Breeches Pockets, and ſlips out.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I profeſs, I can diſcern nothing, but a kind of a glimmering Confuſion,—Moſt Excellent Rabby.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ha!—What now!—He's Vaniſh't, as I live.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Heavens ſhield us!—Indeed I thought the Houſe ſhook.—Strange!—

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Your Cloaths are Vaniſht with him too;—Are not they?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ha.—No,—I ſee 'em there—

div.stage: Sir Cred. takes up his Breeches.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ay!—My Breeches are light, methinks—Heavens!—He's gone with a Hundred Peices, beſides Medals and other Moveables.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: It can't be ſure;—marry he's a Jew indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —A Pox Rabby him, wou'd there were a Hogs-pudding in his Belly.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —See what he has left you in Exchange. in his Prognoſticating Pockets.

div.stage: Sir Cred. gropes, and pulls out a Bill.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —What's here—

—At the Ignoramus-Head in Cabal-Corner, near Treaſon-ſtreet,—Lodgeth the much noted Aſtrologer, Rabbie Nathan the Chaldean, he Reſolves Queſtions, Calculates Nativities, and performs other Secrets, and is to be ſpoke with at his own Lodgings, from Nine till Eleaven, by all ſuch as will make tryal of his Art.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Here's a Cheat!—We'll have it Recorded at Filchers-Hall amongſt the Memoirs o' the Pick-pockets.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Is there no way think you to countermine this Typical Rogue?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Your beſt way will be to go directly to Mr. Zeal's the Conſtables, you remember where I went in, when we parted t'other day.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ay, Very well.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Charge him along with you to Rabby's Lodgings, and if you find him there, take him up.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But I ſhall be too late for my other concern.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —No, no, Rabby does not lodge far off;—'Tis true, the place is Obſcure, but Mr. Zeal's acquainted there, he'll find it out—Make haſte, never ſtay to alter your Habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I approve o' your advice, and will about it with—all Expedition.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I muſt help him to his Moveables again, elſe the Humour wou'd look a little pilfering, and baſe.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: We convey'd your Conjurer out a▪doors▪—What is he, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: A Quacking Bill-poſter by profeſſion; I was a little indebted to him, and Sir Credulous, I thank him has diſcharg'd the trifle.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How have you diſpos'd o' the poor Innocent Knight Sir?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I have furbiſht him out i' the Garb of a Grecian (though he believes 'tis the Habit of an Hebrew, and have directed him to a Conſtable that will ſecure him, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Without any pretence?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You muſt know, I prepoſſeſt him this Morning, that there was a Jeſuit, one Father Wild-fire, about Town, and that I was to be in Company with him about ten of the Clock, and wou'd endeavour ſome occaſion to betray him into his power.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So the Conſtable will have him before Authority?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: No, I advis'd him to ſecure him till I came;—The deſign on't was, to get Sir Popular Marry'd in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You need not ha' given your ſelf ſo much trouble,—It ſeems, my Uncle was impatient, he's gone to Church already, and the Ceremony almoſt over by this time.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Happy News!—I'll away and reſcue Sir Credulous, and be here again preſently.—Your Servant Ladies.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Truly I am very much oblig'd to this Gentleman for his Activity upon my account.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: I'll ſwear he's an Ingenious, good Natur'd Man; have you not obſerved how he wou'd rail againſt the times with Sir Popular, and be ſo ſerious and concern'd all the time; then turn his back, and faſhion a Treacherous Smile;—Well, methinks I cou'd fancy his Humour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So Couſin, you are coming on I find; this Approbation of his Humour, is preliminary to a Paſſion for his Perſon.

sp.speaker: Carol.
sp.p: Indeed, a bold concluſion from ſuch ſlender premiſes;—Is that your Love-Sophiſtry?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: 'Twill be convenient, Madam, that you withdraw; Sir Credulous is coming up.

div.stage: Exit. Carol. and Jul. Enter at the other door Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: You have made a quick return, Sir Credulous.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —My Entertainment did not Invite me to ſtay, I'll promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —What was the matter pray?

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Why, I was almoſt Murther'd amongſt 'em;—The Conſtable was not within, and when I deſir'd one of his Prentices to direct me to Rabby's Lodgings, he ſaid there was no ſuch place i' the City, but houted at me, and expoſed me to the fury of the Rabble, that ſcowr'd after me with Bones and broken Bricks, and if I had not moſt nimbly approach't this Aſylum, they had certainly demoliſht me.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Indeed their behaviour was a little rude to a perſon of your Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —Seriouſly I think 'tis my fortune to fall into the hands of Jews to day; they tell me below, that Sir Popular is gone to perform his Conjugal Rite.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay, and Madam Juliana too.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: And I here?—It can't be.—Pray, explain your meaning.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Why then, ſhe is moſt certainly another Man's Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: —My Lady another Man's Wife ſay you?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Ay, indeed;—and therefore I perſwade my ſelf, that this practice was agreed upon betwixt Rabby and Sir Popular, to hurry you into a confuſion, and ſo preſent him with an opportunity of ſtealing away to Church without ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: Ay, ay, there lay the Intrigue,—I find then Sir Popular has abus'd me.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: If I deal ingeniouſly with you Sir Credulous, believe it to be the effects of my good Wiſhes; therefore to be plain; you have expos'd your ſelf ſo notoriouſly by doating upon ev'ry worthleſs trifle, and buſying your Brain about ſuch odd Fantaſtick Queries, that ev'ry needy Sharping Rook diſcovers your blind ſide, and ſerves his ends upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I hope you won't condemn my Emulation for knowledge.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Firſt, recompoſe your Mind, and endeavour to know more o' the World; leave your nice Contemplations, and obſerve the Publick; you'll ſoon diſcover that my advice was ſeaſonable, take my word.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: I profeſs to you, I do a little fear, I have been impos'd upon o' late; I'll therefore ſcrutiniſe into the Manners of Men, frequent Gaming Houſes, Bowling-Greens, and all ſuch places of Concourſe.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Continue your Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Sir Cred.
sp.p: But how ſhall I proceed with Sir Popular, I wou'd have him notify'd?

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Come, I'll direct you.

div.head: Scene changes to a Dining-Room.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: How do I become my Honour Wench?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: —Wench! I muſt now be Miſtriſs Faith, and your Ladiſhip's Woman.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: But did you obſerve with what ſolemnity Mr. Shuffle gave me Joy?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ay;—I'll ſwear it happen'd well o' his ſide, he has got 500 l. in Gold o' Sir Popular.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —I was afraid, I ſhou'd ha' been diſcover'd upon't, only he help't me well out with it, by ſaying I cou'd not call in any of my own, and therefore he procur'd ſuch a Sum for me.

div.stage: Enter a Pimp and a Carrier.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Madam, I give your Ladiſhip Joy.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p: —Wah they ſay yea'r dub'd a Lady to day, Good Gullman, by my Saul Iſe glad to hear't, maury mickle Glee may you have on't, that's the warſt that I wad ye.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: Upon my Honour good people, I don't know you.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p: —Ah well-a-day, what have you forgotten Honeſt Robbin your and Yorkſhire Carrier, that brought ye up all your Deft Laſſes.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Faith, give the Poor Man 6 d. and ſet him away.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p: —Maury but I mun ha' mare than 6 d. or 6 l. outhor; yea owe me for Nell Bounce, and Beſſy Neſsle ſtill, I reet weel rememmer; an like your Worſhip:

div.stage: Enter Sir Popular, and ſtands privately behind.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: How!—My Lady entertaining two Diſtreſſed French Proteſtants!—Theſe are not people of fit Quality to be ſeen with her I conceive;—but I'll over-hear the occaſion on't.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Upon my honour poor Wretch, I can't underſtand thee.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p: —Lac-a-day, Wah dinnot yea knaw Robbin that us'd to furniſh you with freſh Ware?—I have e'en the Bonnieſt Laſs at my Inn now, for your Worſhip's purpoſe, that ever went Rigledy, Rigledy.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: What's this!—Laſs, and freſh Ware?—Wou'd all things be right.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: —Sure good people you are miſtaken ſomeway; I am not the perſon you ſhou'd addreſs to;—therefore pray walk down, your Company is a diſparagement to my Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: I commend her, ſhe won't make her ſelf little.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: —Pray Madam don't think to put us off ſo; we have forborn you long enough; therefore pray pay me the 5 l. that is due to me.

sp.speaker: Gull.
sp.p: For what Sir?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: —For my diligence in the execution of love buſineſs; you know, at firſt I was only employ'd to fetch and carry; but after, upon experience of my Agility of Body, and ſatisfactory Dimenſions, you were pleas'd to advance me to your higheſt ſtation;—and I think I behav'd my ſelf like a faithful Pains-taker till you left off Bawding▪

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: Ha!—What's that you ſay Sir?—My Lady a Bawd?—Speak—I command you ſpeak.

div.stage: (Gull. ſeems diſorder'd.) Enter Shuffle and Roman.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —I'll ſpeak for him; and can aſſure you, you'r Marri'd to as great a Bawd as ever grac't Cart, with no other Portion than Diſeaſe and Scandal.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: I die, I faint,—Thou Devil,—Thou Damn'd Whore,—I'll murder thee preſently;—Where's my Gutlace,—My Dagger,—My Pocket-Flail.—Oh, oh.—

div.stage: She runs out, Faith after her.

sp.speaker: Carr.
sp.p: Maary honeſt Friend, if ſhe be your Wife, I mun luke o' ye for my Silver; ſhe had good ſound ware o' me, weel I wate, and ſea good Morn to you.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: 'Tis pitty Sir, to let the poor honeſt Carrier ſuffer; if you ſhou'd chance to live together, and keep a Publick Houſe; he'll import another Argoſie, and reſtock your Lady with Merchandiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: O thou baſe, inſulting, Treacherous Rogue; this was thy contrivance, I have Treaſon againſt thee, and will impeach, and hang thee, thou Dog.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Now you remind me on't, I have ſomething againſt your Good Worſhip too, Moſt Noble Patriot.—Here—Serjeants—

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Serjeants do your Office.

sp.speaker: 1. Serj.
sp.p: We Arreſt you in the King's Name, at the Sute of Sir Credulous Trinkett in an Action of a Thouſand Pound.

sp.speaker: Sir Pop.
sp.p: —S'heart, has this Devil here ſerv'd me with an Action;
O my Life, my Name!—Thou Barbarous Raſcal, I will tear theſe Eyes from that Perfidious Skull.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —Officers, away with your Priſoner, and take care he don't do Juſtice on himſelf, and hang himſelf up in his own Chain.

div.stage: Exeunt with Sir Pop. Manent Roman, Shuffle.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Ha, ha,—His Nuptials are Solemniz'd with a Boon Grace methinks.

div.stage: Enter Sir Popular's three Blue-Apron'd Men.

sp.speaker: 1ſt.
sp.p: Good Lord, Mr. Shuffle, Sir Popular's in a wonderful great Agony yonder, it ſeem's he's Marry'd to ſome lewd Woman and is Arreſted.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, your old Patroon is under great Affliction, a groſſer Villain never headed Faction to my knowledge, he only ſtartl'd you with groundleſs fears, to gloze and gull you out of Plentiful Contributions; then laviſh 'em out upon Strumpets.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: —Bleſs us!—Truly it appears ſo now.

sp.speaker: 2d.
sp.p: —Plainly, he has a 100 l. of mine in his hand, for maintenance of the Liberty o' the Subject,——Ah wo'es me!—

sp.speaker: 3d.
sp.p: —And 200 o' mine, by fair Yea and Nay;—I have no other Security, than a Promiſe of re-payment in Lands.—Ah—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Indeed Gentlemen, you have a hopeful Bargain on't: This was your Darling Demagogue that you rever'd.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: —I muſt confeſs, I have been a Raſcal amongſt you, and have concorded with Sir Popular, to baffle, poiſon, and ſeduce you▪ but now my needs are a little mollify'd, and I do therefore recant, and am reſolv'd never to have recourſe to theſe Conſecrated Frauds again.

sp.speaker: 1ſt.
sp.p: —Good Heavens!—How ſtrangely we have been deluded Neighbours—Let's e'en leave Conventickling, take the Oaths, and go to Church.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Now my Friend, go and make your ſelf Maſter of Madam Juliana and Fortunes; I think Sir Popular's Pretences to 'em are diſabl'd.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: —I have reaſon to eſteem thee a Friend indeed▪ That has neglected thy own Intereſt to ſerve me.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: I hope we have contracted ſuch a Tie, as Jealouſie can never violate, or neceſſity betray.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: And now let us confirm it by Alliance;—Madam, you have not vow'd Celibacy I am confident.—She will conſider the Appurtinances of Wit and Good Humour.

sp.speaker: Shuf.
sp.p: Truly ſuch a Fortune wou'd clear my Debts, redeem my Credit, and help me to ſome Honourable Imployment.

lg.l: Of late, like ſome Fat Meteor I've blaz'd,
And with falſe flagrant Zeal, the Croud have 'maz'd;
But now theſe Rays ſhall center in a Star,
Which for the future ſhall be regular.
